member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterOverlayAttributes
member.summary: Contains the overlay attributes of a DICOM image.

remarks.para: This class is used to get or set the various attributes of an overlay image using RasterImage.GetOverlayAttributes and RasterImage.UpdateOverlayAttributes
For more information, refer to Overlay Overview.

member.example: For an example, refer to RasterImage.GetOverlayAttributes and RasterImage.UpdateOverlayAttributes.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterOverlayAttributes.Origin
member.summary: Origin (top left point), in pixels, of the overlay image.
member.value: A that specifies the origin (top left point), in pixels, of the overlay image.

remarks.para: This origin is relative to the top left point of the displayed main image. This is independent of the main image view perspective.
For more information, refer to Overlay Overview.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterOverlayAttributes.AutoPaint
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which determines whether to paint the overlay automatically when the image is painted.
member.value: true to paint the overlay automatically when the image is painted; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: Set the value of this property to true to to paint the overlay automatically when the image is painted (with RasterImagePainter.Paint).
For more information, refer to Overlay Overview.

member.example: For an example, refer to RasterImage.GetOverlayAttributes and RasterImage.UpdateOverlayAttributes.

java.pre: public boolean getAutoPaint() public void setAutoPaint(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterOverlayAttributes.AutoProcess
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which determines whether to automatically adjust the overlay image and position when the main image changes.
member.value: true to automatically adjust the overlay image and position when the image is changed; false, otherwise.

remarks.para: When the value of this property is true, the overlay image and position will automatically adjust when the main image is resized (zoomed in), scrolled, rotated, flipped, reversed, sheared, trimmed.
For more information, refer to Overlay Overview.

member.example: For an example, refer to RasterImage.GetOverlayAttributes and RasterImage.UpdateOverlayAttributes.

java.pre: public boolean getAutoProcess() public void setAutoProcess(boolean value)

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState
member.summary: The state.
member.remarks: This enumeration is used as the state of the . It is used as the value of the RasterImageAnimator.State property and the return value of the RasterImageAnimator.Process method.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.PreClear
member.summary: The initial state of the animation (index = -1). The target image will be cleared to the RasterImage.AnimationBackground color of the current frame on the next call

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.PostClear
member.summary: Indicates that the target image has been cleared

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.PreRender
member.summary: Indicates that the current frame will be rendered to the target image on the next call

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.Render
member.summary: Indicates that a frame has been rendered to the target image

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.PostRender
member.summary: Indicates that a frame is in the midst of being rendered to the target image

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.WaitInput
member.summary: Indicates that the animation engine is waiting for user input before moving on to PreDispose

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.WaitDelay
member.summary: Indicates that the animation engine is waiting for a delayed time before moving on to PreDispose

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.WaitInputDelay
member.summary: Indicates that the animation engine is waiting for user input and a delayed time before moving on to PreDispose

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.PreDispose
member.summary: Indicates that the current frame will be disposed of on the next call

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.PostDispose
member.summary: Indicates that the current frame has been disposed of. The index is incremented after processing this state

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimatorState.End
member.summary: Indicates that the animation is past the last frame in the list (index = number of frames or pages). The animator will loop to index = 0 on the next call with the state set to PreRender

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimator
member.summary: Animates an image that has time-based frames.

remarks.para: To load and play an animated file, such as GIF, you can load the frames into a object from the file, then play the list to a target image in a loop that displays each change in the target image. You can also create an animation sequence from scratch and save the images to create an animated GIF file.

The following is an outline of possible steps:
Load a multi-frame image using
Use the constructor to create a target image that is the size of the images in the multi-frame image
Use the class to create an animation playback that references multi-frame image and the target image
In a loop that processes each frame in the multi-frame image, do the following:
Use RasterImageAnimator.Process to process the current state and get the next state of the animation
Use RasterImageAnimator.GetUpdateRectangle to get the update rectangle (the portion of the target image that has changed)
Use RasterImagePainter.Paint to paint the changed portion of the image. To paint only the changed portion, use the update rectangle as the source clipping rectangle.

The animation loop can have a number of states, and you should only paint the changes in an appropriate state (for example, when the next state is RasterImageAnimatorState.PostRender. For a list of possible states, refer to .

The RasterImage.AnimationDisposalMethod property in the target determines what happens to the image in the playback loop after rendering and after any wait state, when the next state is RasterImageAnimatorState.PostDispose. The options are as follows: keep the image as it is, restore the background, or restore the previous image. (Restoring the background is a common option for animation.)
The animation loop goes continuously through the list of frames. If you want to stop at the end of the list, you can exit the loop when the next state is RasterImageAnimatorState.End.
The class also implements the interface, it is recommended that you follow the standard .NET dispose pattern when using the class. For more information, refer to .

example.para: This example will load an animated GIF file and paint on the surface of the given Panel.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimator.#ctor(Leadtools.RasterImage,Leadtools.RasterImage)
member.summary: Constructs a new object using the specified parameters.
member.param: A object referencing the target image.

A object containing the frames to be played. This object must be a multi-frame image (The value of RasterImage.AnimationGlobalLoop must be something other than -1. You can also pass a null reference (Nothing in VisualBasic) to let the method create an empty multi-frame image.

remarks.para: must be allocated before calling this method

If you pass null (Nothing in VisualBasic) in the parameter, you can use the method to add frames to the multi-frame image during the animation. This is useful if you want to play an animated file as it is being loaded. If you need to reference the multi-frame image after the animation, you can call the method before you dispose this object.
The class also implements the interface, it is recommended that you follow the standard .NET dispose pattern when using the class. For more information, refer to .

member.remarks: For more information, refer to .

member.summary: Releases all the resources used by this .

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimator.Destroy
member.summary: Invalidates this object and returns the animated image.
member.returns: A object containing the multi-frame animated image.

remarks.para: If you pass null (Nothing in VisualBasic) in the animatedImage parameter for the constructor, you can use the method to add frames to the multi-frame image during the animation. This is useful if you want to play an animated file as it is being loaded. If you need to reference the multi-frame image after the animation, you can call the method before you dispose this object.
After you call , this object is invalid and you should only call the method afterwards.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimator.Append(Leadtools.RasterImage)
member.summary: Appends an image to the animated multi-frame image during an animation playback.
member.param: A that contains 1 or more frames to be added to the animation.

remarks.para: If you pass null (Nothing in VisualBasic) in the animatedImage parameter for the constructor, you can use the method to add frames to the multi-frame image during the animation. This is useful if you want to play an animated file as it is being loaded using the Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.LoadImage event. If you need to reference the multi-frame image after the animation, you can call the method before you dispose this object.
After you call , this object is invalid and you should only call the method afterwards.
The method lets you validate the lines that the animation playback engine will render to the target image

example.para: This example plays an animated GIF file as it loads the file

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimator.CancelWait
member.summary: Cancels the wait for user input and any delay during an animation playback.

remarks.para: The "Wait for user input" is supported by GIF89a and later standard. This flag gets set to the corresponding value if this image was loaded from a GIF file. Also, the value set in this property will be used if this image is saved as a GIF file. Otherwise, the LEADTOOLS toolkit will not use the value of this property.

This flag is set in the RasterImage.AnimationWaitUserInput property. The animation playback engine will get into a wait state if it encounters this flag in a frame and the state of the playback will be RasterImageAnimatorState.WaitInput. Use the method to exit the wait state and move to the next frame

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimator.ClearUpdateRectangle
member.summary: Clears the update rectangle used for an animation playback, leaving an empty rectangle.

example.para: This example uses to avoid painting odd numbered frames

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimator.GetUpdateRectangle(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the update rectangle in the target image during an animation playback.
member.param: true if you want to clear the rectangle; false if you do not.
member.returns: A that this method will fill with the coordinates of the update rectangle.
member.remarks:
The rectangle uses image coordinates, and it is cumulative.
You usually call this after the following states, which you can get with the property: ValueMeaning
RasterImageAnimatorState.PostClearIndicates that the target image has been cleared
RasterImageAnimatorState.PostRenderthat a frame has been rendered to the target image
RasterImageAnimatorState.PostDisposeIndicates that the current frame has been disposed of. The index is incremented after processing this state
This method uses image coordinates to specify the update rectangle. Therefore, you must account for the image's view perspective. For more information, refer to Accounting for View Perspective..

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimator.Process
member.summary: Processes the next state during an animation playback.
member.returns: A enumeration member that describes the new state of the animation playback engine

remarks.para: You should call this method in a loop to continually process the playback.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageAnimator.ValidateLines(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Validates lines of an image that was added during a event using the function.
member.param: Row number of the first line in the image to validate. In the event, this corresponds to the first line in the buffer.
Number of lines to validate. In the event, this corresponds to the number of lines in the buffer.

remarks.para: The method enables you to update an image in the event, so that you can play an animation file as it is being loaded. The method lets you validate the lines that the animation playback engine will render to the target image.

If you pass null (Nothing in VisualBasic) in the animatedImage parameter for the constructor, you can use the method to add frames to the multi-frame image during the animation. This is useful if you want to play an animated file as it is being loaded. If you need to reference the multi-frame image after the animation, you can call the method before you dispose this object.
After you call , this object is invalid and you should only call the method afterwards.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.ClearNegativePixelsCommand
member.summary: Sets all pixels with negative color values to 0.

remarks.para: If CodecsLoadOptions.Signed is true when a file is loaded, the image may contain negative pixel values and LEADTOOLS will paint/process the image incorrectly. In order to use this image correctly, you must user . If the CodecsLoadOptions.Signed property is false, all negative pixels are cleared internally, during the load process.
Since some TIFF files are saved with negative values for pixel colors, you should use if, after loading an image, RasterImage.Signed is true. does nothing if RasterImage.IsSigned is false.
Programming tip: use right after loading the image from file.
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.

member.example: This example sets the Signed flag in the load options, loads a tif file and clears the negative pixels.

member.name: T:Leadtools.LeadPoint
member.summary: Stores two integer numbers that represent the coordinates of a point (X and Y).

remarks.para: Various parts of the LEADTOOLS toolkit require a structure that represents a point with X and Y values. Although the .NET framework contains many structures that can be used for this such as System.Drawing.Point and System.Windows.Point, they are tied to specific platforms (GDI+ and WPF/Silverlight in the previous case).
The structure specifies a platform-independent representation of a point. If required, you can convert a structure to a platform-independent point.

member.name: T:Leadtools.LeadRect
member.summary: Stores four integer numbers that represent the coordinates and size of a rectangle (X, Y, Width, and Height).

remarks.para: Various parts of the LEADTOOLS toolkit require a structure that represents a rectangle with location and size values. Although the .NET framework contains many structures that can be used for this such as System.Drawing.Rectangle and System.Windows.Rect they are tied to a specific platform (GDI+ and WPF/Silverlight in the previous case).
The structure specifies a platform independent representation of a rectangle. If required, you can convert to a platform independent rectangle.
To convert a GDI+ System.Drawing.Rectangle (source) to LeadRect, use the following code:

para.c: LeadRect dest = new LeadRect(source.X, source.Y, source.Width, source.Height)

remarks.para: To convert a LeadRect (source) to GDI+ System.Drawing.Rectangle, use the following code:

para.c: System.Drawing.Rectangle dest = new System.Drawing.Rectangle(source.X, source.Y, source.Width, source.Height)

remarks.para: To convert a WPF System.Windows.Rect (source) to LeadRect, use the following code:
To convert a LeadRect (source) to WPF System.Windows.Rect, use the following code:

para.c: System.Windows.Rect dest = new System.Windows.Rect(source.X, source.Y, source.Width, source.Height)

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadRect.Inflate(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Inflates a structure by the specified amount.
member.param: The amount to inflate this horizontally.
The amount to inflate this vertically.

remarks.para: This method inflates this rectangle, not a copy of it. The inflation along an axis is in two directions (minus direction and plus direction). For example, if a 150 by 150 rectangle is inflated by 50 in the x-axis, the resulting rectangle will be 250 units long (the original 150, the 50 in the minus direction, and the 50 in the plus direction) maintaining the rectangle's geometric center. If either width or height is negative, the rectangle structure is deflated in the corresponding direction.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadRect.Inflate(Leadtools.LeadSize)
member.summary: Inflates this structure by the specified amount.
member.param: The amount to inflate this rectangle.

remarks.para: This method inflates this rectangle, not a copy of it. The inflation along an axis is in two directions (minus direction and plus direction). For example, if a 50 by 50 rectangle is inflated by 50 in the x-axis, the resulting rectangle will be 150 units long (the original 50, plus the 50 in the minus direction, and plus the 50 in the plus direction). The rectangle's geometric center is maintained.
If either size.Width or size.Height is negative, the is deflated in the corresponding direction.

java.pre: public void inflate(int width, int height)

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadRect.Inflate(Leadtools.LeadRect,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates and returns an inflated copy of the specified structure. The copy is inflated by the specified amount. The original rectangle remains unmodified.
member.param: The to be copied. This rectangle is not modified.
The amount to inflate the copy of the rectangle along the x-axis.
The amount to inflate the copy of the rectangle along the y-axis.
member.returns: The inflated structure.

remarks.para: This method inflates this rectangle, not a copy of it. The inflation along an axis is in two directions (minus direction and plus direction). For example, if a 50 by 50 rectangle is inflated by 50 in the x-axis, the resulting rectangle will be 150 units long (the original 50, plus the 50 in the minus direction, and plus the 50 in the plus direction). The rectangle's geometric center is maintained.
If either size.Width or size.Height is negative, the is deflated in the corresponding direction.

java.pre: public static LeadRect inflateRect(LeadRect rect, int width, int height)

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadRectHelper.Inflate(Leadtools.LeadRect,Leadtools.LeadSize)
member.summary: Inflates a by the specified amount.
member.param: The rectangle object.
The amount to inflate this horizontally and vertically.
member.returns: The result rectangle.

remarks.para: This method inflates the rectangle itself, not a copy of it. The inflation along an axis is in two directions (minus direction and plus direction). For example, if a 150 by 150 rectangle is inflated by 50 in the x-axis, the resulting rectangle will be 250 units long (the original 150, the 50 in the minus direction, and the 50 in the plus direction) maintaining the rectangle's geometric center. If either width or height is negative, the rectangle is deflated in the corresponding direction.

member.param: A rectangle to intersect.
A rectangle to intersect
member.returns: A third the size of which represents the overlapped area of the two specified rectangles. If there is no intersection, an rectangle is returned.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.FlipCommand
member.summary: Flips a from top to bottom or from left to right.

remarks.para: This command can flip an image from top to bottom (vertically) or from left to right (horizontally).

member.seealso: Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS
member.example: This example will load an image and then flip it before saving it back to disk.

member.name: M:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.FlipCommand.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with default parameters.
member.remarks: Default value for the property is false.

member.name: M:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.FlipCommand.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with explicit parameters.
member.param: true to flip horizontally (left to right), false to flip vertically (top to bottom).

member.returns: string that is the name of this command.

member.summary: Returns a meaningful name for this command.
member.returns: string that is the name of this command.

member.summary: Specifies whether the image is to be flipped horizontally or vertically.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterColor
member.summary: Describes a color consisting of relative intensities of alpha, red, green, and blue.

remarks.para: The LEADTOOLS class provides a platform independent representation of an ARGB color that can be used in any platform supported by LEADTOOLS such as GDI, GDI+, WPF and Silverlight.

To convert a LEADTOOLS object to/from a device dependent color, you can either use the various properties of methods of this class (such as the , , , properties and the RasterColor(int alpha, int red, int green, int blue) constructor) directly, or use the following helper classes:

item.description: Leadtools.Drawing.RasterColorConverter to convert to/from a System.Drawing (GDI+) System.Drawing.Color object.
Leadtools.Windows.Media.RasterColorConverter to convert to/from a System.Windows.Media.Color (WPF and Silverlight) System.Windows.Media.Color object.

member.example: Converts a .NET color to a RasterColor and back.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterColor.Equals(Leadtools.RasterColor,Leadtools.RasterColor)
member.summary: Specifies whether two objects contain the same values.
member.param: The first object to use in the comparison.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.ShearCommand
member.summary: Moves the corners of an image in the fashion of a parallelogram.

remarks.para: You specify an angle of slant, horizontal or vertical shear, and the fill color for the created space. The following is a horizontal example:
The angle is expressed in hundredths of degrees, with a limit of 4500 (45 degrees).
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.

member.example: This example shears the image 15 degrees vertically, filling extra space with blue.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterImageResize
member.summary: Provides support for resizing images.
member.remarks: This class supports changing the color order, bits per pixel and/or palette, during the resize operation.
member.example: This sample loads an image and uses the RasterImageResize class to resize it to half its size.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageResize.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageResize.Start(Leadtools.RasterImage,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterByteOrder,Leadtools.RasterDitheringMethod,Leadtools.RasterSizeFlags,Leadtools.RasterColor[])
member.summary: Sets up information for the method.
member.param: Image to be resized.
New width of the image data.
New height of the image data.
Output bits per pixel. Use 0 for 8-bit grayscale. Possible values are: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 12, 16, 24, 32, 48 and 64.
Output color order.
Flags that indicate the type of dithering, if is not the same as the source image.
Flags that indicate the type of resizing.
The palette to dither to if is less than or equal to 8. Pass a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) to dither to the fixed palette or if no palette is required.

remarks.para: is used when dithering is needed to produce the output bits per pixel. The interpolation usually requires that the input data be converted to 24-bit or 48-bit and then back to the desired bits per pixel. So some dithering might be required if the output bits/pixel are less than or equal to 8.
The method starts the resizing process. This will be followed by calls to to retrieve the resized data and by a call to , to end the resize process and clean up any allocated resources.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImageResize.ResizeBuffer(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves resized data, one line at a time.
member.param: The number of the row to retrieve. The first row is 0, and the last row is 1 less than the image .
The column offset within the row to retrieve. The first column offset is 0, and the last column offset is 1 less than the image .
The buffer to hold the image data that this method gets.
The zero-based index into where retrieving should start.

param.name: bytes
param.para:
The number of bytes to retrieve. Consider the , and avoid specifying a number that goes past the end of the row.
For a 1-bit image, each byte represents 8 pixels.
For a 4-bit image, each byte represents 2 pixels.
For an 8-bit image, each byte represents 1 pixel.
For a 16-bit image, every 2 bytes represents one pixel.
For a 24-bit image, every three bytes represents one pixel.
For a 32-bit image, every four bytes represents one pixel.
For a 48-bit image, every six bytes represents one pixel.
For a 64-bit image, every eight bytes represents one pixel.
You can use the property with integer math to calculate the number of bytes needed for a particular number of pixels. For example:

remarks.para: By using this low-level method to get any part of a row, you can write a procedure that accesses a single pixel or a rectangular area within the image.
This method accepts an offset parameter () in pixels and a length () in bytes. Therefore, you must consider the of the image when specifying these parameters. The following table describes the rules:

tr.td: Must be a multiple of 8 (such as 0,8, or 16).
Can be any number up to the end of the row. Consider that there are 8 pixels per byte.
Must be an even number (such as 0, 2, or 4).
Can be any number up to the end of the row. Consider that there are 2 pixels per byte.
Can be any column within the image.
Can be any number up to the end of the row. Consider that there is 1 pixel per byte.
Can be any column within the image.
Must be a multiple of 2 (such as 2, 4, or 6), because there are 2 bytes per pixel.
Can be any column within the image.
Must be a multiple of 3 (such as 3, 6, or 9), because there are 3 bytes per pixel.
Can be any column within the image.
Must be a multiple of 4 (such as 4, 8, or 12), because there are 4 bytes per pixel.
Can be any column within the image.
Must be a multiple of 6 (such as 6, 12, or 18), because there are 6 bytes per pixel.
Can be any column within the image.
Must be a multiple of 8 (such as 8, 16, or 24), because there are 8 bytes per pixel.

remarks.para: Do not pass a value in that goes past the end of the row. The process is faster when rows are retrieved sequentially, either top-down or bottom-up.
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.

This method accepts an offset parameter () in pixels and a length () in bytes. Therefore, you must consider the of the image when specifying these parameters. The following table describes the rules:

tr.td: Must be a multiple of 8 (such as 0,8, or 16).
Can be any number up to the end of the row. Consider that there are 8 pixels per byte.
Must be an even number (such as 0, 2, or 4).
Can be any number up to the end of the row. Consider that there are 2 pixels per byte.
Can be any column within the image.
Can be any number up to the end of the row. Consider that there is 1 pixel per byte.
Can be any column within the image.
Must be a multiple of 2 (such as 2, 4, or 6), because there are 2 bytes per pixel.
Can be any column within the image.
Must be a multiple of 3 (such as 3, 6, or 9), because there are 3 bytes per pixel.
Can be any column within the image.
Must be a multiple of 4 (such as 4, 8, or 12), because there are 4 bytes per pixel.
Can be any column within the image.
Must be a multiple of 6 (such as 6, 12, or 18), because there are 6 bytes per pixel.
Can be any column within the image.
Must be a multiple of 8 (such as 8, 16, or 24), because there are 8 bytes per pixel.

remarks.para: Do not pass a value in that goes past the end of the row. The process is faster when rows are retrieved sequentially, either top-down or bottom-up.
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.

description.para: For the source image (the image parameter): is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Removed, is the current page (RasterImage.Page) and is 1.
For the destination image (The this or Me in Visual basic image): is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Added, is RasterImage.PageCount since the pages are added at the end and is 1.
For the source image (the image parameter): is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Removed, is the value of the startIndex parameter and is the value of the count parameter.

For the destination image (The this or Me in Visual basic image): is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Added, is RasterImage.PageCount since the pages are added at the end and is the value of the count parameter.

item.description: is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Removed, is the value of the pageIndex and is 1.
is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Removed, is the value of the startIndex parameter and is the value of the count parameter.
is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Removed, is 1 and is RasterImage.PageCount.

description.para: For the source image (the image parameter): is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Removed, is the current page (RasterImage.Page) and is 1.
For the destination image (The this or Me in Visual basic image): is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Added, is the value of the index parameter and is 1.
For the source image (the image parameter): is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Removed, is the value of the startIndex parameter and is the value of the count parameter.
For the destination image (The this or Me in Visual basic image): is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Added, is the value of the index parameter and is the value of the count parameter.

item.description: is RasterImagePagesChangedAction.Removed, is 1 and is the number of pages in the current .

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RotateCommandFlags
member.summary: Flags for the RotateCommand.Flags property.

remarks.para: RotateCommandFlags.Resample and RotateCommandFlags..Bicubic can be combined with RotateCommandFlags.Resize, but they can not be combined with each other. Therefore, you can pass RotateCommandFlags.Resample Or RotateCommandFlags.Resize, but not RotateCommandFlags.Resample | RotateCommandFlags..Bicubic.
If RotateCommandFlags.Resize is set, then the image is resized. Otherwise, the image is cropped.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RotateCommandFlags.None
member.summary: Default, do not resize the image, crop it.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RotateCommandFlags.Resize
member.summary: Size resulting image as needed.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RotateCommandFlags.Resample
member.summary: Perform bilinear interpolation when rotating.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RotateCommandFlags.Bicubic
member.summary: Perform bicubic interpolation when rotating.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RotateCommand
member.summary: Rotates an image by the number of degrees specified.

remarks.para: This command has the following features:

item.description: It uses the center of the image as the center of rotation.
It can rotate the image clockwise or counterclockwise up to 360 degrees in 100th-degree increments.
It can resize the image to accommodate the rotated height and width, or it can retain the original height and width, cropping the image as necessary.
It uses as the background color to fill any new area created by the rotation.

remarks.para: RotateCommandFlags.Resample and RotateCommandFlags.Bicubic can be combined with RotateCommandFlags.Resize, but they can not be combined with each other.
If RotateCommandFlags.Resize is set, then the image is resized. Otherwise, the image is cropped.

Interpolation can be done while rotating certain images. This produces superior output, eliminating the jaggedness occurring when rotating images at angles that are not multiples of 90. (ie when RotateCommand.Angle is not a multiple of 9000).
The only images that are interpolated are:

item.description: 8-bit grayscale images (for best results, all gray values should be in the image palette). If the rotation does not give the expected results, you can use with GrayscaleCommand.BitsPerPixel = 8 to change the image into a proper grayscale image.

12-bit and 16-bit grayscale images that do not have a palette. Grayscale image can have a palette if they have been loaded from certain DICOM images or if the has been used. Use with GrayscaleCommand.BitsPerPixel = 12 or with GrayscaleCommand.BitsPerPixel = 16 if does not seem to do any interpolation during the rotation.

remarks.para: For all other images, ignores the resampling flags and the rotate is performed without interpolation.
For more information, refer to Processing an Image.

member.example: This example will load an image, rotate it by 45 degrees and then save it back to disk

remarks.para: Use this method to process multiple lines of image data. This method is available in the Document/Medical Toolkits.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType
member.summary: List of available metadata comments.
member.keywords: Exif file comments|Exif files|TIFF files|JPEG files|GPS|DICOM|Silverlight|WinRT

remarks.para: When reading or updating Exif comments, you must specify the comment type. Comment fields are constrained by their Exif data type.

All Exif files (TIFF and JPG) can contain the designated TIFF comments. Each TIFF comment field can contain a character string. The maximum field size is 32K, except for the date-time field, which is always 20.
NOTE: Please refer to the EXIF specification for all possible values for EXIF comments.
For more information, refer to GIF File Comments.
For more information, refer to PNG File Comments.
For more information, refer to TIFF File Comments.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Artist
member.summary: Person who created the image. (TIFF Comment)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Copyright
member.summary: Copyright notice. (TIFF Comment)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.DateTime
member.summary: Date and time (YYYY:MM:DD HH:MM:SS). The field length is 20, counting the NULL terminator. (TIFF Comment)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Description
member.summary: Description of the image. (TIFF Comment)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.HostComputer

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Make

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Model
member.summary: Model name and number of the equipment. (TIFF Comment)

member.summary: Name of the document from which the image was scanned. (TIFF Comment)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.NameOfPage

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Software
member.summary: Name and version of the software package used to create the image. (TIFF Comment)

member.summary: Study date (DICOM)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.StudyTime
member.summary: Study time (DICOM)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.StudyReferringPhysician
member.summary: Referring physician (DICOM)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SeriesModality
member.summary: Series modality (DICOM)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SeriesId
member.summary: Series ID (DICOM)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SeriesNumber
member.summary: Series number (DICOM)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.ExifVersion
member.summary: Exif version. LEADTOOLS always writes this value as 0110, meaning version 1.1. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 4.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.DateTimeOriginal
member.summary: Date and time the original image is captured. The format is YYYY:MM:DD HH:MM:SS. The time is in a 24-hour format, and a blank space is left between the date and the time. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 20.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.DateTimeDigitized
member.summary: Date and time the file is generated. If the file is generated directly, as with a digital camera, this is the same as the time the original image is captured. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 20.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.ShutterSpeedValue
member.summary: Shutter speed. The unit of measure is APEX. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Rational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Aperture
member.summary: Aperture value. This is the ratio of lens aperture for the focal length. The unit of measure is APEX. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Brightness
member.summary: Brightness value. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Rational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.ExposureBias
member.summary: Exposure bias. This is the value for correcting a biased exposure. The unit of measure is APEX. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Rational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.MaxAperture
member.summary: Minimum lens f-number. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SubjectDistance
member.summary: Distance from lens to subject (in meters). Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

summary.para: Photometry mode. Possible values are:
Data type: SHORT. Length: 1.
Light source. Possible values are:
Data type: SHORT. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Flash
member.summary:
Flash On/Off. Possible values are 1 for on or 0 for off. Data type: SHORT. Length: 1.
Please refer to the EXIF specification for all possible values for EXIF comments.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.FocalLength
member.summary: Focal length, measured in millimeters. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.ExposureTime
member.summary: Exposure time, expressed as a fraction of a second. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.FNumber
member.summary: The actual lens F stop (ratio of lens aperture to focal length). Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.MakerNote
member.summary: Maker note. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. The creator of the file determines the data format.

summary.para: User comment. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: variable. The first eight bytes specify the data format, and the remainder of the comment is in the specified format. The first eight bytes can be any of the following:

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SubSecTime
member.summary: Decimal extension for seconds that are specified in the RasterCommentMetadataType.DateTime field. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: variable.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SubSecTimeOriginal
member.summary: Decimal extension for seconds that are specified in the RasterCommentMetadataType.DateTimeOriginal field. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: variable.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SubSecTimeDigitized
member.summary: Decimal extension for seconds that are specified in the RasterCommentMetadataType. DateTimeDigitized field. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: variable.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SupportedFlashPixVersion
member.summary: Supported FlashPix version (Exif 2.0). LEADTOOLS always writes 0100 here. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType. Undefined. Length: 4

summary.para: Color space (Exif 2.0). Specifies whether the color is calibrated or not. LEADTOOLS always writes this value as 1. Data type: SHORT. Length: 1 Possible values are:
Exposure program (Exif 2.0) The class of the program used by the camera to set exposure when the picture is taken. Data type: SHORT. Length = 1. Possible values are:

item.description: Creative program (biased toward depth of field)
Action program (biased toward fast shutter speed)
Portrait mode (for closeup photos with the background out of focus)

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SpectralSensitivity
member.summary: Spectral sensitivity (Exif) - The spectral sensitivity of each channel of the camera used. It is an ASCII string compatible with the standard developed by the ASTM technical committee. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: any

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.IsoSpeedRatings
member.summary: ISO speed ratings (Exif) - the ISO speed and the ISO Latitude of the camera or input device as specified in ISO 12232 Data type: SHORT. Length: any

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.OptoElectricCoefficient
member.summary: Optoelectric coefficient (Exif) - Opto-Electric Conversion function specified in ISO 14524. OECF is the relationship between the camera optical input and the image values. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType. Undefined. Length: ANY. This is an array of m rows and n columns.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.RelatedSoundFile
member.summary: Related audio file (Exif) - the name of an audio file related to the image data. The name should be 8 ASCII chars + '.' + 3 chars for extension + NULL. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 13.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.FlashEnergy
member.summary: Flash energy (Exif) - the strobe energy at the time the image is captured, as measured in Beam Candle Power Seconds (BPCS) Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SpatialFrequencyResponse
member.summary: Spatial frequency response (Exif) - the camera or input device spatial frequency table and SFR values in the direction of image width, image height and diagonal direction, as specified in ISO 12233. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: ANY This is an array of m rows and n columns.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.FocalPlaneXResolution
member.summary: Focal plane X Resolution (Exif) - the number of dots per resolution unit on the camera focal plane in the image width (X) direction

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.FocalPlaneResolutionUnit
member.summary: Focal plane resolution unit (Exif). This is the resolution unit for the RasterCommentMetadataType.FocalPlaneXResolution and RasterCommentMetadataType.FocalPlaneYResolution comments.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.FocalPlaneYResolution
member.summary: Focal plane Y Resolution (Exif) - the number of dots per inch on the camera focal plane in the image height (Y) direction

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SubjectLocation
member.summary: Subject location (Exif) - the location of the main subject in the scene. The first value is the X column number and the second is the Y row number. Data type: SHORT. Length: 2

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.ExposureIndex
member.summary: Exposure index (Exif) - the image sensor type on the camera or input device. Data type: SHORT. Length: 1

summary.para: Sensing method (Exif) - the image sensor type on the camera or input device. Data type: SHORT. Length: 1 Possible values are:

File source (Exif) - the image source. If a digital camera recorded the image, the value will always be 3, to indicate that the image was recorded on a digital camera. Data type: SHORT. Length: 1 Possible values are:

item.description: Image recorded on a DSC (Digital Still Camera)

summary.para: Scene type (Exif) - the type of scene. If a DSC recorded the image, this value will always be 1, indicating that the image was directly photographed. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 1 Possible values are:

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.CfaPattern
member.summary: CFA Pattern (Exif) - the color filter array (CFA) geometric pattern of the image sensor when a one-chip color sensor was applied. It does not apply to any other sensing methods. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType. Undefined. Length: ANY This is an array m x n (horz x vertical), where the pattern is repeated every m pixels on the horizontal and n pixels on the vertical.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SubjectArea
member.summary: Location and area of the main subject in the overall scene. Data type: SHORT. Count: 2 (Location of the subject is given in X, Y coordinates), 3 (Area of the main subject is given as a circle, X, Y, D, where X and Y are the center coordinates and D is the diameter.) and 4 (Area of the main subject is given as a rectangle, X, Y, W, H, where X and Y are the center coordinates, W is the width or the rectangle and H is the height of the rectangle.).

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.CustomRendered
member.summary: Use of special processing on image data, such as rendering geared toward output. When special processing is performed, the reader is expected to disable or minimize any further processing. Data type: SHORT; Count: 1; Possible Values: 0 ( Normal process), 1 (Custom process), Other (Reserved). Default: 0;

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.ExposureMode
member.summary: Exposure mode set when the image was shot. In auto-bracketing mode the camera shoots a series of frames of the same scene at different exposure settings. Tag: 41986; Data type: SHORT; Count: 1; Possible values are: 0 (Auto exposure), 1 (Manual exposure), 2 (Auto-bracket), Other (Reserved); Default: none.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.WhiteBalance
member.summary: White balance mode set when the image was shot. Data type: SHORT; Count: 1; Possible values are: 0 (Auto white balance), 1 (Manual white balance), Other (Reserved); Default: none.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.DigitalZoomRatio
member.summary: Digital zoom ratio set when the image was shot. If the numerator of the recorded value is 0, the digital zoom was not used. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational; Count: 1; Default: none.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.FocalLengthIn35MMFilm
member.summary: Equivalent focal length, assuming a 35mm film camera, in mm. A value of 0 means the focal length is unknown. Note that this comment is different from the RasterCommentMetadataType.FocalLength comment. Data type: SHORT; Count: 1; Default: none.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SceneCaptureType
member.summary: Type of scene that was shot. It can also be used to record the mode in which the image was shot. Note that this differs from the RasterCommentMetadataType.SceneType comment. Data type: SHORT; Count: 1; Possible values are: 0 (Standard), 1 (Landscape), 2 (Portrait), 3 (Night scene), Other (Reserved); Default: 0.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GainControl
member.summary: Degree of overall image gain adjustment. Data type: SHORT; Count: 1; Possible values are: 0 (None), 1 (Low gain up), 2 (High gain up), 3 (Low gain down), 4 (High gain down), Other (Reserved); Default: none.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Contrast
member.summary: Direction of contrast processing applied by the camera when the image was shot. Data type: SHORT; Count: 1; Possible values are: 0 ( Normal), 1 (Soft), 2 (Hard), Other (Reserved); Default: 0.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Saturation
member.summary: Direction of saturation processing applied by the camera when the image was shot. Data type: SHORT; Count: 1; Possible values are: 0 ( Normal), 1 (Low saturation), 2 (High saturation), Other (Reserved); Default: 0.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Sharpness
member.summary: Direction of sharpness processing applied by the camera when the image was shot. Data type: SHORT; Count: 1; Possible values are: 0 ( Normal), 1 (Soft), 2 (Hard), Other (Reserved); Default: 0.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.DeviceSettingDescription
member.summary: Information on the picture-taking conditions of a particular camera model. Used only to indicate the picture-taking conditions in the reader. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii; Count: Any; The data is recorded in Unicode using SHORT fro the number of display rows and columns and RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii for the camera settings. The Unicode (UCS -2) string including Signature is NULL terminated. The specifics of the Unicode string are as given in ISO/IEC 10464-1. Default: none.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.SubjectDistanceRange
member.summary: Distance to the subject. Data type: SHORT; Count: 1; Possible values are: 0 (Unknown), 1 (Macro), 2 (Close view), 3 (Distant view), Other (Reserved); Default: none.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.ImageUniqueId
member.summary: Identifier assigned uniquely to each image. It is recorded as an ASCII string equivalent to hexadecimal notation and 128-bit fixed length. Tag: 42016; Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii; Count: 33; Default: none

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.Gamma
member.summary:
Indicates the value of coefficient gamma. The formula of transfer function used for image reproduction is expressed as follows:
(Reproduced value) = (Input value) ^ (gamma).
(The Reproduced and Input values are normalized to be between 0 and 1). The gamma must be positive. Tag: 42240; Data Type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Rational; Count: 1; Default: none.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsVersionId
member.summary: Version number of the GPS image file directory (IFD). The current version is 2.0.0.0. This comment must be included when any GPS comments are used. Unlike the RasterCommentMetadataType.ExifVersion comment, this comment is written in bytes. A version written as 2.0.0.0 is actually 0x02000000 when coded. Data type: BYTE. Length: 4.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsLatitudeRef
member.summary: North or south latitude. Possible values are "N" for north and "S" for south. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 2.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsLatitude
member.summary: Latitude, expressed as three RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational values. When expressed in degrees, minutes, and seconds, latitude is written as dd/1,mm/1,ss/1. If degrees and minutes are used as the units, and minutes are written with fractions to two decimal places, then latitude is expressed as dd/1,mmmm/100,0/1. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 3.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsLongitudeRef
member.summary: East or west longitude. Possible values are "E" for east and "W" for west. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 2.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsLongitude
member.summary: The longitude, expressed as three RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational values. When expressed in degrees, minutes and seconds, longitude is written as ddd/1,mm/1,ss/1. If degrees and minutes are used as the units, and minutes are written with fractions to two decimal places, then longitude is expressed as dd/1,mmmm/100,0/1. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 3.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsAltitudeRef
member.summary: Reference altitude. In the current version, sea level is used as the reference, which must be zero. The reference unit is meters. Data type: BYTE. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsAltitude
member.summary: Altitude, in meters, relative to the reference altitude. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsTimestamp
member.summary: Time stamp in UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) time. The time is expressed as three RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational values, for hours, minutes, and seconds. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 3.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsSatellites
member.summary: GPS satellites used for measurement. The coding format is not stipulated. This comment can be used to code information such as the number of satellites, the satellite number, the satellite angle of elevation, its azimuth, and its SNR. If the GPS receiver cannot make a measurement, this comment is NULL. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: variable.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsStatus
member.summary: Status of the GPS receiver at when the image is recorded. Possible values are "A" when measurement in progress and "V" when measurement is interrupted. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 2.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsMeasureMode
member.summary: GPS measurement mode. A value of "2" denotes two-dimensional measurement, and "3" denotes three-dimensional measurement. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 2.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsDop
member.summary: DOP (data precision) value. This comment is an HDOP value during two-dimensional measurement and a PDOP value during three-dimensional measurement. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsSpeedRef
member.summary: Unit for measuring speed. Possible values are "K" for kilometers, "M" for miles, and "N" for knots. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 2.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsSpeed
member.summary: Speed of the GPS receiver. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsTrackRef
member.summary: Reference for direction of movement. Possible values are "T" for a true direction and "M" for a magnetic. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 2

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsTrack
member.summary: Direction of GPS receiver movement. The range of values is 0.00 to 359.00. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsImageDirectionRef
member.summary: Reference for the direction of photography in the recorded image. Possible values are "T" for a true direction and "M" for a magnetic. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 2.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsImageDirection
member.summary: Direction of photography in the recorded image. The range of values is 0.00 to 359.00. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 1.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsMapDatum
member.summary: Geodetic survey data used by the receiver. If the geodetic survey data is restricted to Japan, this tag value is " TOKYO " or "WGS-84". Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: variable.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsDestinationLatitudeRef
member.summary: North or south latitude for the destination point. Possible values are "N" for north and "S" for south. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 2.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsDestinationLatitude
member.summary: Latitude of the destination point. The latitude is expressed as three RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URationalvalues, indicating degrees, minutes and seconds. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 3.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsDestinationLongitudeRef
member.summary: East or west longitude for the destination point. Possible values are "E" for east and "W" for west. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 2.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsDestinationLongitude
member.summary: Longitude of the destination point. The longitude is expressed as three RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URationalvalues, indicating degrees, minutes and seconds. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.URational. Length: 3.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsDestinationBearingRef
member.summary: Reference for the bearing to the destination point. Possible values are "T" for a true direction and "M" for a magnetic. Data type: RasterCommentMetadataDataType.Ascii. Length: 2.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadataType.GpsDestinationBearing

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadata
member.summary: Extends the class to provide functionality for dealing with comment metadata stored within various image file formats.

remarks.para: The TIFF file formats support a number of comments that are saved and loaded using predefined tags.
If the comments do not meet your needs, you can define your own tag for saving additional non-raster data in a TIFF file. For example, you may want to define a tag to save annotations.

The TIFF 6.0 Specification sets aside a range of private tags that developers can define. To avoid conflicts with files created by other developers, you can register your tag by contacting Adobe Developer Relations. The E-Mail address posted on The Unofficial TIFF Home Page is gapdevsup@adobe.com.
remarks.p: Some restrictions apply to this function if you use an IFD to indicate to which page to write the metadata. See the Loading And Saving Large TIFF Files topic for more information.

member.example: This example will write comments of different data types to an existing tif file then read them as a test.

java.pre: public class RasterCommentMetadata extends RasterMetadata implements Serializable

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterMetadata
member.summary: Provides base functionality for dealing with metadata stored in various image file formats.

remarks.para: "Metadata" refers to extra information that is stored with an image, but is not necessary for decoding the image.

Metadata can contain information about the camera used to take the image, the author, date and time the image was taken, where the image was taken, whether the camera has GPS capabilities, etc. When an image is modified, you should preserve the original information, if possible. Metadata includes markers, tags and comments.
Classes which derive from include:

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadata.IptcSeparator
member.summary: The separator when a file has two or more IPTC comments.

remarks.para: has an ASCII code of 1 and cannot appear in any comment, so there is not a possibility of confusion about this character is the separator or part of the comment. Do not confuse this with the character '1', whose Ascii code is 49!
For more information, refer to IPTC Comments.

java.pre: public static final int IPTC_SEPARATOR = DefineConstants.IPTC_SEPARATOR;

member.name: T:Leadtools.LeadEventsDispatchMode
member.summary: Specifies the mode used to dispatch LEADTOOLS events.

remarks.para: Some LEADTOOLS classes have asynchronous methods that fire events. The class that owns the event will have a DispatchMode property that is used to control how the events are dispatched. In JavaScript, the events must be fired using LeadEventsDispatchMode..

member.name: F:Leadtools.LeadEventsDispatchMode.Direct
member.summary: Indicates the class can fire events caused by asynchronous methods directly. This provides the best performance.

member.name: F:Leadtools.LeadEventsDispatchMode.UseCoreDispatcher
member.summary: Indicates the class must fire events caused by asynchronous methods using the Core Dispatcher. This reduces performance, but ensures events work in JavaScript applications.

remarks.para: For information on when to use and , refer to RasterDefaults.SetRasterImageAllocateCallback.

All members of this class is read-only except for . In other words, you cannot change the width, height, bits/pixel, order or size of the object being created. You can however inspect and change the memory model (conventional, disk, tiled, etc.).

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterDefaults
member.summary: Specifies the default extra values used when creating objects.

remarks.para: You can use the class to specify extra attributes used when creating a object
For example, you can use and to set the physical resolution (DPI) of all the objects creates afterwards.
You can use to specifies the default dithering method to use when converting an image from 64, 48, 32, 24, or 16 bits per pixel to 8 bits per pixel or fewer.
and controls how newly created images use the system memory. The controls where disk-based images are stored.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterDefaults.SetRasterImageAllocateCallback(Leadtools.RasterImageAllocateCallback)
member.summary: Sets a global callback to be called whenever the toolkit is creating a new object.
member.param: Method to be called whenever the toolkit is creating a new object. You can pass null (Nothing in Visual Basic) to stop the toolkit from calling any callback.
member.returns: The previous global callback set, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if no callback was set before (default).

remarks.para: This method allows you to inspect (and change the memory model being used) whenever the toolkit is creating a new object. Generally, you can use the argument to the constructor when creating new objects, however, in some instances, the toolkit will create images internally and you have no control on the memory model being passed. The callback set is global to all LEADTOOLS used in current process.

This can be useful for debugging purposes or to control the memory model of an image being creating internally in LEADTOOLS, for example, as a result of an image processing operation as described in the example.

The return value is the old callback set previously by the user, if no callback was set previously, this method will return null (Nothing in Visual Basic), this allow you to cascade callbacks together.
By default, the toolkit does not set a callback, and calling this method the first time will always return null (Nothing in Visual Basic).
When you are done when the callback, you can call this method with a null (Nothing in Visual Basic) reference to stop the toolkit from calling any methods when creating objects.

example.para: The following example will show how to use the method to stop LEADTOOLS from creating any disk images whatever. The used in the example will internally create a new object. By default, the user has no control on the memory model for this image, however, by using this callback, the user can control (and change) the memory model used.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterDefaults.MaximumThreadCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of threads used during processing.
member.value: An value that represents the maximum number of threads used during processing. Must be a value greater than or equals to 0. Default value is the number of CPUs/Cores in the current machine (System.Environment.ProcessorCount).

remarks.para: Note: this property is currently supported by LEADTOOLS for Silverlight only.

Using two threads with a dual core machine or two CPUs will increase the processing speed significantly if the processing supports parallel processing. Currently only the LEADTOOLS JPEG2000 Encoder and Decoder are using this property. More LEADTOOLS encoders/decoders may use this property in the future.
Possible values are:

description.para: The toolkit will pick the proper number of running threads based on the number of CPUs/Cores of the current machines. Note: the toolkit will calculate this value internally and set it. Getting the value of this property will never return 0.

item.description: Use one thread only. In this case, the toolkit will not create extra threads for the processing, instead, all operations will be performed in the main thread.
Use two threads. The toolkit will create a maximum of two threads for processing if needed.
Use N threads. The toolkit will create a maximum of N threads for processing if needed.

remarks.para: Values less than zero will be rejected. Large values, more than the number of CPU/Cores, will not increase performance and might cause resource usage overload which could lead to processing failure.
The property is a global resource used by all LEADTOOLS and is not thread-safe. Make sure to use property thread synchronization if required.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.GrayscaleCommand
member.summary: Converts a 1-, 4-, 8-, 16-, 24-, or 32-bit image to an 8-bit, 12-bit, or 16-bit grayscale image.

remarks.para: Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale images is available only in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
The resulting image can be an 8-bit, 12-bit, or 16-bit grayscale image. Once the function is complete, the RasterImage.GrayscaleMode property will indicate the type of grayscale image.

When converting to 12-bit or 16-bit grayscale, the RasterImage.GetLookupTable is not used. When converting to 8-bit grayscale, the RasterImage.GetLookupTable is used to get the RGB for each input pixel. The grayscale value corresponding to that RGB triple is used in the destination image.
remarks.p: This method does not support signed images.
remarks.para: For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.
For more information, refer to Grayscale Images.

member.example: This example will load a 24-bit image then convert it to a grayscale image with 8, 12 and 16 bits/pixel

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CopyRectangleCommand
member.summary: Copies a portion of an image to create another image that is the size of the rectangle that you specify.

remarks.para: This command duplicates the original image palette, if one is required in the new image.

This command uses image coordinates to specify the area to be copied. Therefore, you must account for the RasterImage.ViewPerspective of the image. For information about image coordinates, refer to Accounting for View Perspective.
If a region is defined for the source image, the region is also copied, and the region is clipped if necessary.
The command works by creating a new image in the property from the image passed to the method.

member.example: This example will create a new image from the top left portion of an existing image.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RasterCommandProcessorCancel
member.summary: Indicates whether or not to continue with the image processing command.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RasterCommandProcessorCancel.None
member.summary: Default, continue normally.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RasterCommandProcessorCancel.Command
member.summary: Stop the current command, but continue with the next command in the collection.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RasterCommandProcessorCancel.Image
member.summary: Stop the current command, but only for the current image. Continue with the current command on the next image in the collection.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.RasterCommandProcessorCancel.All
member.summary: Stop the process completely, aborting all commands on all images.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags
member.summary: Indicates how the range is used to fill and type of the the lookup table and whether it contains signed or unsigned data.
member.remarks:
These flags have a attribute that allows a bitwise combination of its member values.
You can use a bitwise OR (|) to specify one flag from each group.
GroupFlags
Flags that indicate how the range is used to fill the LUTInside, Outside
Flags that indicate the LUT typeLinear, Exponential, Logarithmic, Sigmoid
Flags that indicate whether the LUT contains signed or unsigned dataSigned
Flag that indicate whether to fill the LUT using only the startColor and endColor color parameters of , as used in DICOM applications.DicomStyle

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.None
member.summary: Default

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Inside
member.summary: Fill the lookup table between Low and High. ( inside the Low...High range )

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Outside
member.summary: Fill the LUT below the low and above the high parameters of and everything in between.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Linear
member.summary: Lookup table is linear

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Exponential
member.summary: Lookup table is exponential

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Logarithmic
member.summary: Lookup table is logarithmic

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Sigmoid
member.summary: Lookup table is sigmoid

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Signed
member.summary: The lookup table data is signed

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.DicomStyle
member.summary: Fill using the startColor and endColor parameters of colors only.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterPalette
member.summary: Encapsulates and provides support for managing image palettes.

For more details, refer to Introduction: Palette Handling.

member.example: For an example, refer to and .

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterPalette.Fixed(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates an array of objects that represent the LEAD Fixed palette.
member.param: The number of colors to add to the fixed palette.
member.returns: The LEAD Fixed palette.
member.remarks:
The number of colors specified in controls the type and size of the returned palette: countLEAD Fixed palette
21-bit palette, with 2 colors, black and white.
42-bit palette, with 4 colors.
83-bit palette, with 8 colors.
164-bit palette, with 16 colors.
325-bit palette, with 32 colors.
646-bit palette, with 64 colors.
1287-bit palette, with 128 colors.
2568-bit palette, with 256 colors.

member.summary: Creates an array of objects that represent the Netscape Fixed palette.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterPalette.WindowLevelFillLookupTable(Leadtools.RasterColor[],Leadtools.RasterColor,Leadtools.RasterColor,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags)
member.summary: Fills the user-allocated 8-bit LUT with values ranging between the and colors according to the selected LUT type.
member.param: Pointer to an array to be updated with the 8-bit RGB quad (i.e. lookup table).
Starting color value for the gradient.
Ending color value for the gradient.
The low value of the window width, in pixels.
The high value for the window width, in pixels.
Value indicating the low bit used for leveling. This is normally 0 and should be less than the .
Value indicating the high bit used for leveling. This should be greater than or equal to and less than 11 for 12-bit grayscale or 15 for 16-bit grayscale.
The image minimum value. This value can be obtained using .
The image maximum value. This value can be obtained using .

param.name: factor
param.para: Value that indicates the factor to be applied in the method operation specified in the parameter.
This parameter is used only if is RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Exponential, RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Logarithmic or RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Sigmoid.

If RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Exponential or RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Sigmoid is specified, its value can be any integer (+/-). If RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Logarithmic is specified, its value should be >>= 0. If = 0, the lookup table will be filled linearly.

member.param: Flags that indicate how the range is used to fill and the type of the lookup table and whether it contains signed or unsigned data.

remarks.para: This method is available in the Medical Toolkits.
Use this method to fill in the lookup table, used in RasterImage.WindowLevel, according to the lookup table type flag.
The lookup table will be filled as follows:

tr.td: solid black (0,0,0)
color gradient ranging from to
solid white (255,255,255)
solid color ()
grayscale values from solid black (0,0,0) to solid white (255, 255, 255)
solid color ()
RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Inside | RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.DicomStyle
None
color gradient ranging from to
None
RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.Outside | RasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags.DicomStyle
solid color ()
color gradient ranging from to
solid color ()

remarks.para: To fill a 16-bit lookup table use .
Only TIFF and DICOM file formats are capable of saving images that have been window-leveled.

Images can be window-leveled by calling RasterImage.WindowLevel and specifying RasterWindowLevelMode.PaintAndProcessing for the parameter, by using the or by loading an image from a file format that supports Window Leveling.
If a window-leveled image is saved as any other file format, the image data will be converted before being saved. For more information, refer to Saving Window-Leveled Images.

LEADTOOLS supports two types of LUTs for 10-16-bit grayscale images (8-bit LUT and 16-bit LUT). Typical grayscale image display and processing is done using an 8-bit LUT. But, you can also use a 16-bit LUT, which offers more precision. Some special video cards and monitors also support display of grayscale images using a 16-bit LUT.
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.
For more information, refer to Grayscale Images.

objectivec.pre: +(BOOL)windowLevelFillLookupTable:(NSArray*)lookupTable startColor:(LTRasterColor*)startColor endColor:(LTRasterColor*)endColor low:(int)low high:(int)high lowBit:(unsigned int)lowBit highBit:(unsigned int)highBit minValue:(int)minValue maxValue:(int)maxValue factor:(int)factor flags:(LTRasterPaletteWindowLevelFlags)flags error:(NSError**)outError;

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.ClearCommand
member.summary: Sets all bits to 0 in the specified image, making it a black image.

remarks.para: Sets all bits to 0, in the specified image. If the image has a palette, all pixels will be the color of the first palette entry.
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.

member.example: This example will clear an image before saving it back to disk.

member.name: M:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.ClearCommand.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with default parameters.

member.name: M:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.ClearCommand.ToString
member.summary: Overridden. Returns a meaningful name for this command.
member.returns: string that is the name of this command.

member.name: M:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.ClearCommand.GetStringDescription
member.summary: Returns a meaningful name for this command.
member.returns: string that is the name of this command.

member.name: T:Leadtools.LeadFileStream
member.summary: The class provides an implementation of the interface that operates on a disk file.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs a new object using the specified buffer as storage.
member.param: The path to a file that will be used as storage for the new object.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.Start
member.summary: Called to start using the object.
member.returns: true if the object can be used.

remarks.para: Call this method before using the object.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.Stop(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called to stop using the object.
member.param: Resets the stream position to the original value.

remarks.para: Call this method when the object is no longer needed.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.OpenFile(System.String,Leadtools.LeadStreamMode,Leadtools.LeadStreamAccess,Leadtools.LeadStreamShare)
member.summary: Creates, opens or reopens the specified file.
member.param: The relative or absolute path for the file that this object will be associated with.
A constant that determines how to open or create the file.
A constant that determines how the file can be accessed by this object.
A constant that determines how the file will be shared by processes.
member.returns: true if the file is open; false, otherwise.
member.remarks: Use the interface to perform read and write operations.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.Read(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Reads a specified number of bytes from the object and writes the data into the specified buffer.
member.param: The buffer to write the data into.
The maximum number of bytes to read.
member.returns: The total number of bytes read into the buffer. The result value can be less than the number of bytes requested if the number of bytes currently available is less than the requested number, or it can be 0 (zero) if the end of the stream has been reached

remarks.para: Use the property to determine whether the current instance supports reading.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.Write(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Writes the specified number of bytes to the object.
member.param: The buffer containing data to write to the stream.
The maximum number of bytes to write.
member.returns: The total number of bytes written into the object.

remarks.para: Use the property to determine whether the current instance supports reading.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.Seek(Leadtools.LeadSeekOrigin,System.Int64)
member.summary: Sets the current position of this object to the specified value.
member.param: Specifies the beginning, the end, or the current position as a reference point for , using a value of type .
The point relative to from which to begin seeking.
member.returns: The new position in the stream

remarks.para: Use the property to determine whether the current instance supports reading.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.CloseFile
member.summary: Closes this object and releases any resources associated with it.

member.name: P:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.Buffer
member.summary: Gets the internal IBuffer that this object uses for storage.
member.value: The internal IBuffer that this object uses for storage.

member.name: P:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.CanSeek
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current object supports seeking.
member.value: true if the object supports seeking; false, otherwise.

remarks.para: If the object is closed, this property returns false.

member.name: P:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.CanRead
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current object supports reading.
member.value: true if the object supports reading; false, otherwise.

remarks.para: If the object is closed, this property returns false.

member.name: P:Leadtools.LeadFileStream.CanWrite
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current object supports writing.
member.value: true if the object supports writing; false, otherwise.

remarks.para: If the object is closed, this property returns false.
