member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterRegionCombineMode
member.summary: Controls the creation of an image region.

summary.para: The resulting region includes only the intersection of the existing region and the new one. The following example shows the result, where the rectangles represent the existing region, the ellipse represents the new one, and the shaded area represents the resulting region.

The resulting region includes only the new region. The existing region, if any, is discarded. The following example shows the result, where the ellipse is the new region and the shaded area is the resulting region.

The resulting region includes the intersection of the area outside the existing region and the area inside the new region. The following example shows the result, where the rectangle is the existing region, the ellipse is the new one, and the shaded area is the resulting region.

img.alt: Raster Region Combine Mode: AND NOT

summary.para: The resulting region includes the intersection of the area inside the existing region and the area outside the new region. The following example shows the result, where the rectangle is the existing region, the ellipse is the new one, and the shaded area is the resulting region.

img.alt: Raster Region Combine Mode: AND NOT Region

summary.para: The resulting region includes the area inside the existing region and the area inside the new region. The following example shows the result, where the rectangle is the existing region, the ellipse is the new one, and the shaded area is the resulting region.

The resulting region includes the area inside the existing region and the area inside the new region, except for any areas where the two intersect. The following example shows the result, where the rectangle is the existing region, the ellipse is the new one, and the shaded area is the resulting region.

The resulting region includes everything in the image, except the new region. The existing region, if any, is discarded. The following example shows the result, where the ellipse is the new region and the shaded area is the resulting region.

img.alt: Raster Region Combine Mode: SET NOT

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags
member.summary: Indicates the type of memory to allocate.
member.remarks: For more information, refer to Memory Storage Types for Images.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags.None
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags.Conventional
member.summary: Use conventional memory.

summary.para: Create an image where the user maintains the data pointer.

Some image processing commands, such as and , need to re-allocate the image data. If you create a bitmap with RasterMemoryFlags.User, and pass it to these command, they will change the bitmap to RasterMemoryFlags.Conventional and re-allocate memory. Your original memory will no longer be used.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags.Tiled
member.summary: Create an image where the data pointers are maintained in tiles, useful for very large images. This is currently not supported by LEADTOOLS for Silverlight.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags.NoTiled
member.summary: Do not allow tiled images.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags.Disk
member.summary: Do not use managed memory. Swap to disk only. This is currently not supported by LEADTOOLS for Silverlight. If the image is allocated as Disk, then the image should not be used in multiple threads.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags.NoDisk
member.summary: Do not swap to disk using LEAD virtual memory. Windows virtual memory is not affected.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags.Compressed
member.summary: (Document/Medical only) Allocate an RLE-compressed image. You can use this flag with None or NoDisk. For more information, refer to Speeding Up 1-Bit Documents. This is currently not supported by LEADTOOLS for Silverlight.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags.SuperCompressed
member.summary: (Document/Medical only) Allocate a CMP-compressed image. You can use this flag with None or NoDisk. This is currently not supported by LEADTOOLS for Silverlight.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags.WriteableBitmap
member.summary:
(Document/Medical only) Use a Silverlight for memory storage.
This option works only for 32-bit images.
This is supported only in LEADTOOLS for Silverlight..

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterGetSetOverlayImageMode
member.summary: Determines how to set or retrieve the overlay .

remarks.para: This enumeration is used for the mode parameter for RasterImage.GetOverlayImage and RasterImage.SetOverlayImage.
For more information, refer to Overlay Overview.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterGetSetOverlayImageMode.Copy
member.summary: A copy of the overlay image is retrieved/inserted from/into the overlay list.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterGetSetOverlayImageMode.NoCopy
member.summary: The actual overlay image is retrieved/inserted. No copy is made.

summary.para: For RasterImage.GetOverlayImage, the actual overlay image is retrieved. The image is also removed from the overlay list
For RasterImage.SetOverlayImage, the overlay image is moved into the overlay list. It will also be reset, so you cannot make changes to it.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterUpdateOverlayBitsFlags
member.summary: Determines whether the main image or the overlay image should be updated.

remarks.para: For more information, refer to Overlay Overview.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterUpdateOverlayBitsFlags.None
member.summary: No action.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterUpdateOverlayBitsFlags.FromOverlay
member.summary: Update the main image bits for the corresponding bitplane using the data from the overlay image.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterUpdateOverlayBitsFlags.FromImage
member.summary: Update the overlay image with the bits from the corresponding bit plane of the main image. Can be or-ed with Clear

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterUpdateOverlayBitsFlags.Clear
member.summary: Clears the bits from the bitplane associated with the overlay that are not contained in the overlay image (use only in combination with FromOverlay)

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterPaintSizeMode
member.summary: Determines how to fit the image in the destination rectangle.
member.remarks: Used by the the RasterImage.CalculatePaintModeRectangle method to determines how to fit the image in the destination rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaintSizeMode.Normal
member.summary: Normal, no sizing

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaintSizeMode.Fit
member.summary: Fit the image into the destination rectangle while maintaining the aspect ratio. If the image size is smaller than the destination rectangle, no resizing is done

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaintSizeMode.FitAlways
member.summary: Always fit the image into the destination rectangle while maintaining the aspect ratio even if the image size is smaller than the destination rectangle

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaintSizeMode.FitWidth
member.summary: Fit the image width to be the size of the width of the destination rectangle while maintaining the aspect ratio

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaintSizeMode.Stretch
member.summary: Fit the image to fill the destination rectangle. Aspect ratio might not be maintained.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaintSizeMode.FitHeight
member.summary: Fit the image height to be the size of the height of the destination rectangle while maintaining the aspect ratio

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterPaintAlignMode
member.summary: Determines how to align the image in the destination rectangle.
member.remarks: Used by the the RasterImage.CalculatePaintModeRectangle method to determines how to align the image in the destination rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaintAlignMode.Near
member.summary: Align the image to the left (if this is the horizontal alignment) or top (if this is the vertical alignment) of the destination rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaintAlignMode.Center
member.summary: Center the image in the middle of the destination rectangle. If the image size is greater than the destination rectangle size then do not center the image.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaintAlignMode.CenterAlways
member.summary: Center the image in the middle of the destination rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterPaintAlignMode.Far
member.summary: Align the image to the right (if this is the horizontal alignment) or bottom (if this is the vertical alignment) of the destination rectangle.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterSizeFlags
member.summary: Flags which control the behaviour of image resize methods.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterSizeFlags.None
member.summary: Resize normally

summary.para: (Document/Medical only) Preserve black objects when making the image smaller. This option affects only 1-bit, black-and-white images, where it prevents the disappearance of thin lines. You can use a bitwise OR ( | ) to combine this flag with another one. For example, Resample | FavorBlack causes color images to be resampled, but applies the favor-black option to 1-bit, black-and-white images.
If you apply this flag to an image that has more than 1 bit per pixel, then the behavior is undefined.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterSizeFlags.Resample
member.summary: Use linear interpolation and averaging to produce a higher-quality image

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterSizeFlags.Bicubic
member.summary: Use bicubic interpolation and averaging to produce a higher quality image. This is slower than Resample

summary.para: (Document/Medical only). Use interpolation to display black and white images using shades of gray when the image is resized. This improves the readability when the image is scaled up or down. The generated image is 8-bit grayscale, so this option should be used only for black and white images.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineWarpCommand
member.summary: Combines image data from the source image (the slave) and the destination image (the master), using a perspective warp.

remarks.para: You can warp the entire source image, or a portion of the source image. To warp a portion of the source image, set accordingly. To warp the entire source image, set the following:
The warp area in the destination image is specified in . The polygon specified in must:

item.description: Fit entirely on the destination bitmap

remarks.para: If either of these conditions is false, this class will throw an exception.
The ordering of the points in can affect the resulting warp. For example, if the source image is the following:
then ordering the points in as shown below results in the following warp:
while ordering the points in as shown below, results in the following warp:
The works by combining the image in the property with the image passed to the method. The will then hold the result of the combine operation..
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.
This command does not support signed data images.

The class contains the and events. These events will fire whenever objects are added or removed to/from the collection.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterCollection`1.OnItemAdded(Leadtools.RasterCollectionEventArgs{`0})
member.summary: Raises the event.
member.param: An that contains the event data.

remarks.para: Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
The OnItemAdded method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
Notes to Inheritors: When overriding OnItemAdded in a derived class, be sure to call the base class OnItemAdded method so that registered delegates receive the event.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterMemoryThreshold
member.summary: Holds the memory restrictions used when allocating new objects.
member.keywords: Memory|Memory Threshold|Memory Allocation|Thresholds|Conventional Memory| Allocate|Conventional Buffers
member.remarks: Use the class to get or set the memory restrictions used when allocating new objects.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterMemoryThreshold.Empty
member.summary: Returns a new empty object.
member.value: The object this property creates.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterMemoryThreshold.TiledThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the minimum amount of free memory required to allow the allocation of conventional images.
member.value: An integer value that specifies the minimum amount of free memory required to allow the allocation of conventional images. Default value is 0.

remarks.para: If the amount of free memory falls below this threshold, all images will be allocated as tiled. The exception is when the image size is smaller than the tile size - in this case, the image will be allocated in conventional memory.
Values less than -100 are not allowed.
If the value is < 0, it represents the required number of free bytes.
If the value is 0, then there is no minimum requirement for free memory, all images are allocated as conventional if there is enough memory.

Tiled images use a combination of memory tiles and disk tiles. When an image is allocated, LEADTOOLS decides how many conventional memory tiles and how many disk tiles should be allocated. The value influences the number of conventional tiles allocated as follows: the toolkit will not allocate any more conventional tiles when the amount of memory falls below . When the amount of memory falls below , disk tiles will be allocated and several swap buffers might back these disk tiles. For each image there will be at least one swap tile.

If the value is > 0, then it represents a percentage of free memory out of the total memory. For example, when you pass -20, tiled images will be used when the amount of free physical and swap memory will drop below 20 percent of the total memory.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterMemoryThreshold.MaximumConventionalSize
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the maximum size for a conventional image (default is 0x7FFFFFFF).
member.value: An integer value that specifies the maximum size for a conventional image (default is 0x7FFFFFFF).

remarks.para: Any images with a size bigger than this will be allocated as tiled.
If the value is > 0, then it represents the maximum size in bytes.
If the value is < 0, then it represents the maximum size in percentage of the total memory (physical and swap).
Values less than -100 are not allowed.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterMemoryThreshold.TileSize
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the size for a size of the tile for tiled images.
member.value: An integer value that specifies the size for a size of the tile for tiled images. Default is 0

remarks.para: The value for must be less than the value of .
All images with a size smaller than will be allocated as conventional. (A tiled image of a size smaller than would consist of only small tile, which is the equivalent of the conventional image).
If is 0, then LEADTOOLS will pick a default size for the tile. (Currently it is 16MB)
The tiles will be smaller than this value and will be a complete number of rows. No rows will be split between tiles.
Values less than 0 are not allowed.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterMemoryThreshold.ConventionalTiles
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the maximum number of tiles that will reside in conventional memory at any time.
member.value: An integer value that specifies the maximum number of tiles that will reside in conventional memory at any time. Default is 0.

remarks.para: is used when working with a tiled image. The tiles that do not reside in conventional memory will be on disk. (Default is -100 = all tiles are in memory)
If the value is > 0, then this parameter represents the number of tiles.
If the value is 0, then all the tiles in a tiled image will be disk tiles.
If the value is < 0, then this parameter represents the percentage of tiles that will reside in memory.
Values less than -100 are not allowed.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterMemoryThreshold.ConventionalBuffers
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the number of buffers in conventional memory that will cache the disk tiles.
member.value: An integer value that specifies the number of buffers in conventional memory that will cache the disk tiles. Default is 1 (one swap buffer will be used to cache the disk tiles).

remarks.para: is used when working with tiled images which have disk tiles. The swap buffers will greatly improve the access to these disk tiles.
If the value is > 0, indicates the number of swap buffers.
If the value is < 0, - indicates the percentage of the total of disk tiles. For example, -50 means the number of buffers is half of the disk tiles will be used.
If the value is 0, no swap buffers will be used. This uses the least amount of memory.

It is useful to have more than one swap buffer when you have an algorithm that constantly reads data going up and down. Usually, the data is read in one direction (from top to bottom or bottom to top) - in this case, one swap buffer will be enough. Also, if you only view a certain portion of the image, you might benefit from having enough swap buffers to cache the visible portion of the image (or the image's region).

The buffers are dynamic: when data is being read/written to a disk tile, a cache buffer is created (if permitted and there is enough memory). If the maximum number of cache buffers for that image has been reached, the cache buffer for the last used tile will be deleted and used for the new tile.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterBufferConverter.Convert(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterByteOrder,Leadtools.RasterByteOrder,Leadtools.RasterColor[],Leadtools.RasterColor[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterConvertBufferFlags)
member.summary: Converts data in the specified buffer to the specified bits per pixel and color order.
member.param: The input buffer.
The zero-based offset into the where conversion should start.
Width in pixels of the input image data.
BitsPerPixel of the input image data.
BitsPerPixel of the desired output image data.
The input color order.
The output color order.
The palette or 8-bit LUT for the existing data, before conversion. If the input data is not palettized and not grayscale, use NULL.
The palette for the converted data. If the data is converted to 16 or 24 bits per pixel color, use NULL for no palette.
Value indicating the low bit in the source buffer, if the source buffer contains grayscale data.
Value indicating the high bit in the source buffer, if the source buffer contains grayscale data.
The alpha value if the destination bits per pixel contains an alpha component
Flags indicating whether to treat 16 bit data as grayscale or color.

remarks.para: Note: This method will also work for 12 and 16-bit grayscale images, but only in the Document/Medical Imaging editions. If you attempt to use this method with a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image, but you do not have a Medical Imaging edition, it will throw an exception.
The conversion uses only one buffer, which must be large enough to hold the data before and after conversion.

Image data that is 8 bits per pixel or less must use a palette, and this method can use such data as input, output, or both. Therefore, you may need to specify the palette for the input, or for the output, or both.
If either or is 16, is used to determine whether the data should be treated as color or grayscale.

If nBitsPerPixelSrc is 12, it is assumed to be grayscale. However, the parameter should also reflect that it is grayscale for future compatibility. If the source is grayscale, can be set to a palette. The palette should contain N entries. If the source uses and , then N equals 2 raised to the power of ( - + 1). Otherwise, N equals 2 raised to the power of .
The parameter supersedes and . If you specify RasterByteOrder.Bgr for , but use RasterConvertBufferFlags.SourceGray in , it will be assumed that the source buffer contains grayscale data.
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.

member.seealso: Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS

The parameter supersedes and . If you specify RasterByteOrder.Bgr for , but use RasterConvertBufferFlags.SourceGray in , it will be assumed that the source buffer contains grayscale data.
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.

member.seealso: Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS

member.summary: Converts data in the specified unmanaged memory buffer to the specified bits per pixel and color order.
member.param: The input buffer.
Width in pixels of the input image data.
BitsPerPixel of the input image data.
BitsPerPixel of the desired output image data.
The input color order.
The output color order.
The palette or 8-bit LUT for the existing data, before conversion. If the input data is not palettized and not grayscale, use NULL.
The palette for the converted data. If the data is converted to 16 or 24 bits per pixel color, use NULL for no palette.
The 16-bit LUT for the existing data, before conversion. Use NULL for no 16-bit LUT.
The 16-bit LUT for the converted data. Reserved for future use. Use NULL.
Value indicating the low bit in the source buffer, if the source buffer contains grayscale data.
Value indicating the high bit in the source buffer, if the source buffer contains grayscale data.
The alpha value if the destination bits per pixel contains an alpha component
Flags indicating whether to treat 16 bit data as grayscale or color.

remarks.para: Note: This method will also work for 12 and 16-bit grayscale images, but only in the Document/Medical Imaging editions. If you attempt to use this method with a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image, but you do not have a Medical Imaging edition, it will throw an exception.
The conversion uses only one buffer, which must be large enough to hold the data before and after conversion.

Image data that is 8 bits per pixel or less must use a palette, and this method can use such data as input, output, or both. Therefore, you may need to specify the palette for the input, or for the output, or both.
If either or is 16, is used to determine whether the data should be treated as color or grayscale.

If nBitsPerPixelSrc is 12, it is assumed to be grayscale. However, the parameter should also reflect that it is grayscale for future compatibility. If the source is grayscale, can be set to a palette. The palette should contain N entries. If the source uses and , then N equals 2 raised to the power of ( - + 1). Otherwise, N equals 2 raised to the power of .
The parameter supersedes and . If you specify RasterByteOrder.Bgr for , but use RasterConvertBufferFlags.SourceGray in , it will be assumed that the source buffer contains grayscale data.
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.

member.seealso: Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterCurveType
member.summary: Indicates the type of curve that is being defined.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCurveType.Bezier
member.summary: A series of Bezier curves that use the points as control points. In this case, the number of points must be 3n + 1, where n >= 1. For example, number of points can be 4, 7, 10, 13, and so on. The first four points define the first Bezier curve, and each subsequent group of three points defines the next Bezier curve, using the last point of the previous Bezier curve as the starting point.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCurveType.Standard
member.summary: A smooth curve that goes through all of the points. In this case, there must be at least three points.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterCurveClose
member.summary: Indicates how to close the curve.

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCurveClose.NoClose
member.summary: For n points, draw (n - 3) segments. For example, for points {P0, P1, P2, P3, P4}, draw segments P1P2 and P2P3

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCurveClose.Close
member.summary: For n points draw (n) segments. For example, for points {P0, P1, P2, P3, P4}, draw segments P0P1, P1P2, P2P3, P3P4, P4P0

member.name: F:Leadtools.RasterCurveClose.PartialClose
member.summary: For n points draw (n - 1) segments. For example, for points {P0, P1, P2, P3, P4}, draw segments P0P1, P1P2, P2P3, P3P4 (but not P4P0)

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterCurve
member.summary: Defines a curve.

remarks.para: The class defines the curve to be used with the method to draw a curve using an array of objects. The method is used to convert a curve to a Bezier. The class can define two types of curves, RasterCurveType.Standard and RasterCurveType.Bezier.

member.example: This sample creates a smooth region that goes through five points, and inverts the region.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterCurve.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterCurve.ToBezierPoints
member.summary: Converts the curve points to an array of Bezier points.
member.returns: An array of values that contain the Bezier points.

remarks.para: This method is used to convert a standard curve to an array of Bezier control points. A standard curve (RasterCurveType.Standard) is defined by the current . The standard curve passes through all of the points in the collection, and is continuous at each point. This method can be used to draw a curve by converting it to an array of Bezier points, using System.Drawing.Graphics.DrawBeziers to draw the equivalent Bezier(s).

member.example: This sample draws a smooth closed curve on a graphics that goes through five points.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterCurve.Type
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates the type of curve being defined.
member.value: A enumeration value that indicates the type of curve being defined.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterCurve.Points
member.summary: The curve points.
member.value: A collection of objects that define the curve points.
member.remarks:
The number of points in the collection obey the following rules:
If is RasterCurveType.Bezier, the number of points in must be 3n + 1, where n >= 1. For example, the number of points can be 4, 7, 10, 13, and so on.
If is RasterCurveType.Standard, the number of points in must be greater than or equal to 3. For example, the number of points can be 3, 4, 5, 6, and so on.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterCurve.FillMode
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates how to handle complex crossing lines.
member.value: A enumeration value that indicates how to handle complex crossing lines.

item.description: All pixels that are inside the resulting exterior lines are in the region.
The region includes the area between odd-numbered and even-numbered polygon sides on each scan line.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterCurve.Tension
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates how straight to make the curves that connect points.
member.value: An value that indicates how straight to make the curves that connect points. Valid values are between 0.0 and 1.0.

remarks.para: This value is used only when is RasterCurveType.Standard. Valid values are between 0.0 and 1.0, where 0.0 indicates straight lines, and 1.0 indicates lines with the highest curvature. A typical value for dTension is 0.5.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterCurve.Close
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates how the curve is closed.
member.value: A enumeration value that indicates how the curve is closed.

remarks.para: Refer to for more information.
In the following diagram, the resulting region is shown in gray:

member.name: T:Leadtools.LeadBufferStream
member.summary: The class provides an implementation of the interface that operates on a memory buffer.

remarks.para: The class uses an IBuffer for the stream's storage. This class supports read, write and seek operations.

java.pre: public final class LeadBufferStream implements ILeadStream

member.summary: Constructs a new object using the specified buffer as storage.
member.param: An IBuffer that will be used as storage for the new object.
The offset in that will be used as the origin of the new object.
Value that indicates whether should be disposed when the new object is disposed.

remarks.para: If is true, then the will dispose when it is disposed.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadBufferStream.#ctor(System.Byte[],System.UInt64)

member.param: A byte array that will be used as storage for the new object.
The offset in that will be used as the origin of the new object.

member.summary: Called to start using the object.
member.returns: true if the object can be used.

remarks.para: Call this method before using the object.

member.name: M:Leadtools.LeadBufferStream.Stop(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called to stop using the object.
member.param: Resets the stream position to the original value.

remarks.para: Call this method when the object is no longer needed.

The maximum number of bytes to read.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.ResizeCommand
member.summary: Resizes the image from an existing image, and puts the resized image into a destination image, leaving the original image intact.

remarks.para: The command works by resizing the image data passed to the method into the image passed to the property.
The destination image must be initialized with the correct RasterImage.Width and RasterImage.Height of the new, resized image.
This command does not change the source image passed to the method. If you want to resize an image without creating a new version, use the .
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.

member.example: This example will load an image then resize into an existing smaller image

Flags that determine resizing options.

remarks.para: The command works by resizing the image data passed to the method into the image passed to .
The destination image must be initialized with the correct RasterImage.Width and RasterImage.Height of the new, resized image.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CreateGrayscaleImageCommand
member.summary: Converts a 1-, 4-, 8-, 16-, 24-, or 32-bit to an 8-bit, 12-bit, or 16-bit grayscale image.

remarks.para: The command works by creating a new image in the property from the image passed to the method.
The destination image will have either 8, 12, or 16 bits/pixel grayscale values.

When converting to 12-bit or 16-bit grayscale, a Lookup table (LUT) is not used. When converting to 8-bit grayscale, a LUT is used to get the RGB for each input pixel. The grayscale value corresponding to that RGB triple is used in the destination image
and are used when converting to 12-bit or 16-bit grayscale, So the appropriate values must set before calling the method.
This command does not support 32-bit grayscale images.
This command does not support signed images.

member.seealso: Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS
member.example: This example loads an image and changes it to 16-bit grayscale.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterBufferResize.ResizeBuffer(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Resizes a buffer to the new size specified with the method.
member.param: The buffer containing the original scanline to be resized.
Zero-based index into the .
Current row of the original bitmap.
Bits per pixel, which is the same for the original and the resized bitmap.

remarks.para: contains the buffer containing a line from the original image to be resized. Your code must allocate the buffer and copy the data into it before calling this method.

The same buffer holds the data before and after it is resized. Therefore, the buffer must be big enough to hold whichever is larger. (The original line is larger when reducing an image; the resulting line is larger when enlarging the image.)
Before calling this function, you must call the method.
When all lines have been processed, you must call the method.
For more information, refer to Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterBufferResize.LineWidth
member.summary: Holds the resulting line width of the resized image data.
member.value: The resulting line width of the resized image data.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterBufferResize.CopyRepetitions
member.summary: Holds the required number of copy repetitions.
member.value: The number of times needed to copy the new resized line buffer to the new image.

remarks.para: When an image is being enlarged, some lines must be copied more than once. When an image is being reduced, some lines must be eliminated (not copied at all).

For example:
A value of 0 means that the line should not be copied.
A value of 1 means that the line should be copied once.
A value of 2 means that the line should be copied twice.
And so on ....

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterSupport.SetLicense(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the runtime license for LEADTOOLS and unlocks support for optional features such as LEADTOOLS Imaging Pro, Document and Medical capabilities, or PDF support.
member.param: Character string containing the name of the LEADTOOLS runtime license file to load.
Character string containing the developer key.

remarks.para: You must use this function to set the runtime license for LEADTOOLS and to unlock support for any optional features that you have licensed. If you do not set a runtime license, your application will display a "nag" message dialog at runtime, indicating that you have developed the application without a valid runtime license.
In order to obtain a runtime license and developer key, you must contact LEAD. For more information, refer to About LEADTOOLS Runtime Licenses.
For information about LEADTOOLS Document/Medical capabilities, contact LEAD.
To determine if support for optional features has been unlocked, use
To set the runtime license from a memory buffer instead of disk file, use SetLicense(byte[] licenseBuffer, string developerKey).
NOTE: As an alternative to calling RasterSupport.SetLicense, you can specify your runtime license in the Leadtools.dll.config file. For more information, see LEADTOOLS Config License.

NOTE: To set a server license, call SetLicense with the license server information in the parameter.
RasterSupport.SetLicense("", "10.0.1.1;31001;MyApplication"); // host;port;appName

remarks.para: If you set a valid runtime license for your application using , then you do not need to call this static method.

If you do not set a valid runtime license for your application using , then you must call this static method prior to using any other LEADTOOLS functionality. This method must be called from the main / UI thread of your application. Failure to call this method as described above will cuase other LEADTOOLS methods to throw a Kernel Expired exception or behave in an undefined manner.

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterSupport.KernelType
member.summary: Gets the type of the LEADTOOLS kernel.
member.value: Aa enumeration member indicating the LEADTOOLS kernel type.
member.remarks:
There are 3 types of LEADTOOLS kernels, as described in the following table: KernelDescription
Release This is the Release kernel.
Nag This is a special build of the kernel, which has specialty features (such as Document Imaging and Medical Imaging) unlocked. This kernel is provided to Document and Medical imaging customers, and displays a "nag" message during execution. To remove the nag, you must sign a royalty agreement. For more information, contact sales@leadtools.com.
Evaluation This is the Evaluation kernel, which has all features unlocked, but displays an "eval" message during execution. This kernel will also expire.
member.example: This example will check the LEADTOOLS kernel type and whether it has expired

member.name: P:Leadtools.RasterSupport.KernelExpired
member.summary: Checks whether the LEADTOOLS kernel has expired.
member.value: true if the LEADTOOLS kernel has expired; false, otherwise.

member.summary: Gets the status of the LEADTOOLS Config License.

member.remarks: Check this property to determine the status of the LEADTOOLS Runtime License that was set in the LEADTOOLS Config License.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterRegionXForm
member.summary: Provides data for translating between region coordinates and external representations of those coordinates.

remarks.para: All region methods accept a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic). In that case, no transformation occurs. The scalar fields default to 1, the offsets default to 0, and the view perspective defaults to the image view perspective.

Several of the LEADTOOLS methods for creating and working with an image region use coordinates from an external representation of the region, such as a shape drawn in a device context. To compensate for possible differences in view perspective, scaling, and display offsets, these LEADTOOLS methods require that you provide translation information in an object.

In most cases, the external representation of an image region is scaled and positioned relative to the display coordinates of a LEADTOOLS painting method. Therefore, the following table describes the fields to set in the object, based on the parameters of the display methods.
When assigning an external representation to an image, every point (Xa, Ya) in the an external representation is transformed (by ) to point (Xc, Yc) in the image region as follows:

para.code:
1. Add offsets: Xb = Xa + XForm.XOffset Yb = Ya + XForm.YOffset
2. Multiply by scalars: Xc = (Xb * XForm.XScalarNumerator) / XForm.XScalarDenominator Yc = (Yb * XForm.YScalarNumerator) / XForm.YScalarDenominator
3. Compensate for view perspective (updating Xc and Yc in place): PointToImage(XForm.ViewPerspective, Xc, Yc)

remarks.para: When retrieving an external representation from an image, every point (Xa, Ya) in the image region is transformed (by ) to point (Xc, Yc) in the external region as follows:

para.code:
1. Compensate for view perspective (updating Xa and Ya in place): PointFromImage(XForm.ViewPerspective, Xa, Ya)
2. Mulitply by scalars: Xb = (Xa * XForm.XScalarNumerator) / XForm.XScalarDenominator Yb = (Ya * XForm.YScalarNumerator) / XForm.YScalarDenominator
3. Add offsets: Xc = Xb + XForm.XOffset Yc = Yb + XForm.YOffset

remarks.para: For more information, refer to Translating Coordinates for a Region..

member.seealso: Working with the Existing Image Region
Commands and Methods That Transform The Region And the Image
member.example: For an example, refer to RasterRegion.Transform.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterTagMetadata
member.summary: Extends the class to provide functionality for dealing with tag metadata stored within various image file formats.

remarks.para: The TIFF file formats support a number of comments that are saved and loaded using predefined tags.
If the comments do not meet your needs, you can define your own tag for saving additional non-raster data in a TIFF file. For example, you may want to define a tag to save annotations.

The TIFF 6.0 Specification sets aside a range of private tags that developers can define. To avoid conflicts with files created by other developers, you can register your tag by contacting Adobe Developer Relations. The E-Mail address posted on The Unofficial TIFF Home Page is gapdevsup@adobe.com.
remarks.p: Some restrictions apply to this function if you use an IFD to indicate to which page to write the metadata. See the Loading And Saving Large TIFF Files topic for more information.

member.example: This example will save then load some tags to/from a tif file.

java.pre: public class RasterTagMetadata extends RasterMetadata implements Serializable

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags
member.summary: Flags for the CombineFastCommand.Flags.

remarks.para: These flags are divided into four groupings: source (SRC) flags, destination (DST) flags, operation (OP) flags, and resulting image (RES) flags. The flags apply only to the defined rectangles (not necessarily the whole image). The flags are applied in the following order:

list.item: Operations on the source and destination rectangles are applied. These are implemented at the same time.
Operations on the resulting rectangle are applied.

remarks.para:
You can use a bitwise OR (|) to specify one flag from each group.
GroupFlags
Flags that define treatment of the source rectangleNone, SourceNot, Source0, Source1
Flags that define treatment of the destination rectangleDestinationNot, Destination0, Destination1
Flags that define the operation to use when combining the dataOperationOr, OperationXor, OperationAdd, OperationSubtractSource, OperationSubtractDestination, OperationMultiply, OperationDivideSource, OperationDivideDestination, OperationAverage, OperationMinimum, OperationMaximum
Flags that define treatment of the resulting image rectangleResultNot, Result0, Result1, SourceCopy
For more options use .

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.None
member.summary: No change. Part of the group of flags that define treatment of the source rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.SourceNot
member.summary: Invert the color, resulting in its complement. Part of the group of flags that define treatment of the source rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.Source0
member.summary: Change all bits to 0. Part of the group of flags that define treatment of the source rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.Source1
member.summary: Change all bits to 1. Part of the group of flags that define treatment of the source rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.DestinationNot
member.summary: Invert the color, resulting in its complement. Part of the group of flags that define treatment of the destination rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.Destination0
member.summary: Change all bits to 0. Part of the group of flags that define treatment of the destination rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.Destination1
member.summary: Change all bits to 1. Part of the group of flags that define treatment of the destination rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationOr
member.summary: Combine each set of bytes using a bitwise OR ( | ). Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationXor
member.summary: Combine each set of bytes using a bitwise exclusive OR (^). Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationAdd
member.summary: Add the byte values, allowing a maximum of 255. Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationSubtractSource
member.summary: Subtract the source from the destination, allowing a minimum of 0. Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationSubtractDestination
member.summary: Subtract the destination from the source, allowing a minimum of 0. Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationMultiply
member.summary: Multiply the byte values, allowing a maximum of 255. The result is calculated as follows: result = (source * dest) / 255. Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationDivideSource
member.summary: Divide the destination by the source. If source > 0, then the result is calculated as follows: result = min( (dest / source) * 255, 255 ). Otherwise, if source = 0, then result = 255. Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationDivideDestination
member.summary: Divide the source by the destination. If dest > 0, then the result is calculated as follows: result = min( (source / dest) * 255, 255 ). Otherwise, if dest = 0, then result = 255. Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationAverage
member.summary: Use the average of the two values. Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationMinimum
member.summary: Use the lesser of the two values. Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.OperationMaximum
member.summary: Use the greater of the two values. Part of the group of flags that define the operation to use when combining the data.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.ResultNot
member.summary: Invert the color, resulting in its complement. Part of the group of flags that define treatment of the resulting image rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.Result0
member.summary: Change all bits to 0. Part of the group of flags that define treatment of the resulting image rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.Result1
member.summary: Change all bits to 1. Part of the group of flags that define treatment of the resulting image rectangle.

member.name: F:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommandFlags.SourceCopy
member.summary: Copies the source image to the destination image.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CombineFastCommand
member.summary: Combines image data from two images (source and destination), letting you specify the areas to be combined and the operations to be performed when combining the data.

remarks.para: As an example, suppose you use class to apply an edge detection filter. You can then use this class to combine the resulting image with the original one to produce an image with hard edges.
The CombineFastCommand class works by combining the image in the property with the image passed to the method. The will then hold the result of the combine operation.

The CombineFastCommand flags are divided into four groupings: source (SRC) flags, destination (DST) flags, operation (OP) flags, and resulting image (RES) flags. The flags apply only to the defined rectangles (not necessarily the whole image). The flags are applied in the following order:

list.item: Operations on the source and destination rectangles are applied. These are implemented at the same time.
Operations on the resulting rectangle are applied.

remarks.para:
You can use a bitwise OR (|) to specify one flag from each group.
GroupFlags
Flags that define treatment of the source rectangleNone, SourceNot, Source0, Source1
Flags that define treatment of the destination rectangleDestinationNot, Destination0, Destination1
Flags that define the operation to use when combining the dataOperationOr, OperationXor, OperationAdd, OperationSubtractSource, OperationSubtractDestination, OperationMultiply, OperationDivideSource, OperationDivideDestination, OperationAverage, OperationMinimum, OperationMaximum
Flags that define treatment of the resulting image rectangleResultNot, Result0, Result1, SourceCopy
Certain flags when combined have no meaning:

list.item: Setting the flag (RES flags) to either CB_RES_0 or CB_RES_1 will render the rest of the flags useless.
Setting the SRC and DST flags to CB_SRC_0 and CB_DST_0 respectively, then the OP flags (the operation flags) will be useless.
Setting the SRC and DST flags to CB_SRC_1 and CB_DST_1 respectively, then the OP flags (the operation flags) will be useless.
Setting the flag (OP Flags) to CB_OP_ADD or CB_OP_OR or CB_OP_MAX, while setting the (SRC flags) to CB_SRC_1 will make the (DST flags) useless.
Setting the flag (OP Flags) to CB_OP_ADD or CB_OP_OR or CB_OP_MAX, while setting the (DST flags) to CB_SRC_1 will make the (SRC flags) useless.

remarks.para: For more options, like specifying the color plane, use .
For more information, refer to Processing an Image.

member.example: The following example loads two images and combines them using an "AND" operation.

member.name: T:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CloneCommand
member.summary: Creates a copy of a a object.

remarks.para: After the command is run, a copy of the current page of the source image will be in the CloneCommand.DestinationImage property. This property will hold a copy of the image, so the user is responsible for freeing this image after using it.
If a region is defined for the image, the region is also copied.
If the source image has more than one page, then you can use the CloneCommand.AllPages property to control whether to clone all the pages in the image or only the current page.

You can use the RasterImage.Clone method instead of this command to create a clone of an image. If you need to clone a multi-page object, then use the RasterImage.CloneAll method. These methods will also clone any metadata (tags, comments and markers) located in the source image however, you lose the benefit of using a progress monitor.

example.para: This example will load an image and then clone it before saving it back to disk. For an example on how to clone a multi-page image and show the overall progress monitor, refer to the CloneCommand.AllPages property.

member.name: P:Leadtools.ImageProcessing.CloneCommand.AllPages
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether to clone all the pages if the source image is multi-page.
member.value: true to clone all the pages if the source image is multi-page; false, otherwise.

remarks.para: If the source image (the image passed to the RasterCommand.Run method) contains multiple pages, then you can use the property to control whether the will create a copy of the current active page or all the pages in the image.

Note that when the source image has multiple pages and the value of was set to true, then the RasterCommand.Progress event will fire from 0 to 100 for each page processed. If an overall progress percentage is desired, then you can inspect the RasterImage.Page and RasterImage.PageCount properties of the property to calculate this value as shown in the example below.
The default value of this property is false to clone only the current page.

example.para: This example will clone a multi-page image and shows the over-all progress value.

java.pre: public final boolean getAllPages() public final void setAllPages(boolean value)

Note that when the source image has multiple pages and the value of was set to true, then the RasterCommand.Progress event will fire from 0 to 100 for each page processed. If an overall progress percentage is desired, then you can inspect the RasterImage.Page and RasterImage.PageCount properties of the property to calculate this value as shown in the example.
The default value of this property is false.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterColorTypeConverter
member.summary: Converts objects from one data type to another. Access this class through the

remarks.para: To convert a to a string value, use the RasterColor.ToString method.

You can use the members of this class to convert a string to a value. You can also use the helper static (Shared) RasterColorTypeConverter.ConvertFromString method directly without creating a instance.
Currently, this class supports converting a to and from a string type only. The string can be in an HTML compatible format.

member.summary: Inflates a by the specified amount.
member.param: The rectangle object.
The amount to inflate this horizontally and vertically.
member.returns: The result rectangle.

remarks.para: This method inflates the rectangle itself, not a copy of it. The inflation along an axis is in two directions (minus direction and plus direction). For example, if a 150 by 150 rectangle is inflated by 50 in the x-axis, the resulting rectangle will be 250 units long (the original 150, the 50 in the minus direction, and the 50 in the plus direction) maintaining the rectangle's geometric center. If either width or height is negative, the rectangle is deflated in the corresponding direction.

member.name: T:Leadtools.RasterImage
member.summary: The class serves as a working area for image manipulation and conversion. LEADTOOLS functions use this class for accessing the image in memory and for maintaining the characteristics of the image.

remarks.para: The class is used to work with images defined by pixel data.

The class contains methods and properties for dealing with images in memory. You can use this class to create images from scratch or load them from disk based files. Also, various other components of LEADTOOLS for .NET creates objects from operations such as scanning and OCRing. The class is the main LEADTOOLS object used when passing image data between different parts of the toolkit.

The class lets you deal with individual rows or pixels of the image data. This class also contains methods and properties for the following:
Creating images
Accessing the image data
Adding regions to the image
Setting/Changing the palette for an image
Converting an image to a GDI or GDI+ Image through the Leadtools.Drawing.RasterImageConverter class
Creating a GDI HDC or GDI+ Graphics object from an image through the Leadtools.Drawing.RasterImagePainter class
Painting an image to a GDI or GDI+ surface through the through the Leadtools.Drawing.RasterImagePainter class
Converting an image to a WPF or Silverlight Image through the Leadtools.Windows.Media.RasterImageConverter class
The class implements the interface and thus supports standard .NET serialization. For more information and examples regarding serialization of an object, refer to RasterImage Serialization.

The class also implements the interface, it is recommended that you follow the standard .NET dispose pattern when using the class. For more information, refer to the interface documentation in MSDN, the property and the RasterImage.Disposed event.

The LEADTOOLS class supports storing images in memory in the following bits per pixel: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 12, 16, 24, 32, 38 and 64. A 16-bpp image may be color or grayscale. If you are working with a 16-bit grayscale image. Support for 8-bit and 12-bit grayscale images is also provided.
The data of a object can be stored in memory as uncompressed, RLE compressed or super compressed. Support for super compressing bitmaps is available only in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
The object can also store its data in disk-based swap files when conventional memory is not enough.
The object can hold multiple pages with different sizes. The , , and methods allows adding new pages to an existing .
The , and methods allows removing existing pages from a object.
The and methods allows replace existing pages in a object.
The property holds the total number of pages in a object while the property allows you to change the current active page.
The current active page (The page indicated by the property) is used by default when accessing the data of a object unless otherwise indicated.

The object also contains a region of interest value that can be used to limit the portion available to update when using the image processing command. The region can be set using a geometric shape such as and or with image data attributes such as and .

member.example: This example loads an image file from a disk file, and processes the image data before saving it back to disk.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.#ctor(Leadtools.RasterMemoryFlags,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterByteOrder,Leadtools.RasterViewPerspective,Leadtools.RasterColor[],System.IntPtr,System.Int64)
member.summary: Constructs a new object using the specified parameters and optional unmanaged memory.
member.param: A combination of the enumeration members indicating the type of memory to allocate for the image data.
Width of the image in pixels.
Height of the image in pixels.

param.name: bitsPerPixel
param.para: The number of bits per pixel.
Use 0 to create an 8-bit grayscale image. In that case, the method ignores the and the parameters.

param.name: order
param.para: Color order for 16-, 24-, 32-, 48- and 64-bit images.
If the resultant image is less than 16 bits per pixel, this will have no effect since palletized images have no order.

param.name: viewPerspective
param.para: Specifies where the beginning of the image is stored.
Most file formats start in the lower left corner while some formats start in the upper left corner.

member.param: The palette that the image will use. You can specify your own palette, or use null (Nothing in Visual Basic) for LEAD's fixed palette. The member is used only when is less than or equal to 8.

param.name: userData
param.para: Unmanaged data pointer that will contain the image data when is RasterMemoryFlags.User.
This data must be aligned on a four byte boundary. If is IntPtr.Zero, the data pointer must be passed later, by calling the method, before the image can be used.

member.param: Length in bytes of the data passed to . Only when used when is not IntPtr.Zero and is RasterMemoryFlags.User.

remarks.para: Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
There is some speed penalty (loss) for accessing RasterMemoryFlags.Tiled images. Therefore, it is not recommended for use with all images.

The RasterMemoryFlags.Tiled images are not used by default. LEADTOOLS will create them only if it failed to create RasterMemoryFlags.Conventional images and RasterMemoryFlags.NoTiled was not specified.

The following lists the distinct types of bitmaps:
Conventional (uncompressed and contiguous) This is the most common type.
Compressed (1-bit only)
Tiled (uncompressed, stored internally as up to 64MB tiles)
If you pass RasterMemoryFlags.User, you are responsible for freeing the image data.

Creating an image of type RasterMemoryFlags.User does not allocate memory for the image data. Instead, the data pointer is used. When you create a with user data, the and flags will both be set to true. Some image processing commands, such as , need to re-allocate the image data. If you create an image with RasterMemoryFlags.User, and pass it to these methods, the data will be re-allocated internally by LEADTOOLS and the image object will stop using the data in .
For more information, refer to Accounting for View Perspective.
For more information, refer to Grayscale Images.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.DisableEvents
member.summary: Disables raising the event.

remarks.para: Calling will increment an internal counter. When the internal counter is 0, the events will be raised for changes to the .
When the internal counter is != 0, will not be raised. Therefore, for each call to , there should be a corresponding call to in order to restore the raising of events.

You can temporary disable the event when performing multiple operations on a object then re-enabling it once the operations are done. This way, any listeners to the event will be notified only once thus optimizing the performance.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.CreateThumbnail(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterViewPerspective,Leadtools.RasterSizeFlags)
member.summary: Creates a thumbnail image of this RasterImage.
member.param: The desired maximum width of the thumbnail image in pixels.
The desired maximum height of the thumbnail image in pixels.
The desired bits per pixel.
The desired view perspective.
Flags that control the resize operation.
member.returns: A new RasterImage that is the thumbnail image.

remarks.para: If the image width and height is less than thumbnailWidth and thumbnailHeight, then this method returns a copy of the image in the original size.

If the image width or height is greater than thumbnailWidth and thumbnailHeight, then this method will return the biggest thumbnail it can fit into the dimensions specified by thumbailWidth and thumbnailHeight, keeping the original image aspect ratio.
The result image will always have a resolution of 96 by 96 regardless of the resolution this and will never return a thumbnail bigger than the original image.

member.summary: Removes all pages from this .

remarks.para: This method will remove all but the current active page from this . The current active page is the page with index equal to . Since you cannot have a with no pages, calling this method will result in a object with exactly 1 page.
The object can hold multiple pages with different sizes. The , , and methods allows adding new pages to an existing .
The , and methods allows removing existing pages from a object.
The and methods allows replace existing pages in a object.
The property holds the total number of pages in a object while the property allows you to change the current active page.
The current active page (The page indicated by the property) is used by default when accessing the data of a object unless otherwise indicated.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.GetPalette
member.summary: Gets a copy of the palette of this object that will be used by 1-8 bit color or grayscale image.
member.value: An array of containing the palette for this object. If this object does not contain a palette, null (Nothing in Visual Basic) is returned.

remarks.para: The palette is used for 1-8 bit color or grayscale image rendering. Image is grayscale when red, green and blue (R=G=B) components for each palette entry has the same value.
The image data of a object with values of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 or 8 consists of an index into the image palette. You can get a copy of the palette used by using the method.
You can change the palette used by the object with the method.
remarks.p: This method does not support signed images.
remarks.para: For more information, refer to and Introduction: Palette Handling.
For information on 10 to 16-bit grayscale image, refer to the Grayscale Images.

member.example: For an example, refer to and .

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.GetLookupTable
member.summary: Gets the 8-bit lookup table (LUT) of this .
member.returns: An array of structures which represent the lookup table (LUT) of this .

remarks.para: The lookup table (LUT) is used when the value of is set to true.

The 8-bit and 16-bit lookup tables are synchronized, so when you change one, the other is changed as well The 16-bit lookup table () has more precision so it is recommended you use the 16-bit LUT instead of the 8-bit LUT.
LUT is also used for displaying extended Palette color image such as bit stored is 16-bit and LUT contains color value. This is typical of Ultra Sound image.
For more information, refer to Grayscale Images.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.SetLookupTable(Leadtools.RasterColor[])
member.summary: Sets the 8-bit lookup table (LUT) of this .
member.param: An array of structures which represent the lookup table (LUT) of this .

remarks.para: The lookup table (LUT) is used when the value of is set to true.

The 8-bit and 16-bit lookup tables are synchronized, so when you change one, the other is changed as well The 16-bit lookup table () has more precision so it is recommended you use the 16-bit LUT instead of the 8-bit LUT.
LUT is only used for 10-16 bit extended grayscale image or 10-16 bit palette color image. To update the palette in 1-8 bit image use . For more information, refer to Grayscale Images.
LUT is also used for displaying extended Palette color image such as bit stored is 16-bit and LUT contains color value. This is typical of Ultra Sound image.

member.summary: Removes the region from the image and frees the memory used for the region.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.CalculateRegionMaximumClipSegments
member.summary: Gets the number of elements required to hold the clip segments for any row in the region.
member.returns: The maximum number of segments in a row within the region.

remarks.para: Use this method in conjunction with .
For more information, refer to Working with the Existing Region.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.GetRegionClipSegments(System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the segments contained in the region for a particular row.
member.param: The number of the row for which to get the segments. The first row is 0, and the last row is 1 less than the image height.
Buffer to be updated with the segments from contained in the region.
Zero based index into .
member.returns: The number of segments from that are contained in the region.

remarks.para: To use this method, first call with the xform set to null (Nothing in Visual Basic), to get the image boundaries. The bounding rectangle will indicate which rows are contained in the region. Go through all the rows contained in the region to get the segments contained in the region.

The segments are returned as an array of pairs of horizontal offsets. The first point in the pair is the beginning of the segment (it is contained in the region). The last point in the pair is the end of the segment. To follow the Windows rules, the end of the segment is the first point NOT CONTAINED in the region.
In most regions, there will be one segment per row. However, some regions can have 0, 1, 2 or more segments.

For example, assume that for a particular row there are two segments. will be filled with 4 values. Let's call them x0, x1, x2, x3. In this case:
portion from 0 to x0 - 1 is OUTSIDE the region
portion from x0 to x1 - 1 is INSIDE the region
portion from x1 to x2 - 1 is OUTSIDE the region
portion from x2 to x3 - 1 is INSIDE the region
portion from x3 to - 1 is OUTSIDE the region

member.example: This example sets the value of pixels inside a region to half intensity.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.GetRegion(Leadtools.RasterRegionXForm)
member.summary: Gets the object that describes this current region.
member.param: object that LEADTOOLS uses to translate between display coordinates and image coordinates. If you specify null (Nothing in Visual Basic) for this parameter, the scalar fields default to 1, the offsets default to 0, and the view perspective defaults to the image view perspective.
member.returns: An object that describes this current region.

remarks.para: To set or updated the object that describes the current image region, use .
If the image does not have a region, this method will return an empty object.

The class provides a platform independent representation of a region of interest in an image that can be used in any platform supported by LEADTOOLS such as GDI, GDI+, WPF and Silverlight. The class contains extensive methods and properties to manipulate the region data and save/load it to a byte array.
To convert a LEADTOOLS object to/from a device dependent region, you can use the following helper classes:

item.description: Leadtools.Drawing.RasterRegionConverter to convert to/from a System.Drawing (GDI+) System.Drawing.Region or Windows HRGN objects.
Leadtools.Windows.Media.RasterRegionConverter to convert to/from a WPF and Silverlight System.Windows.Media.Geometry object.

remarks.para: The class implements the interface, so you must call on any region objects you create after using it.
For more information, refer to Creating a Region.
For more information, refer to Saving A Region.
For more information, refer to Working with the Existing Region.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.SetRegion(Leadtools.RasterRegionXForm,Leadtools.RasterRegion,Leadtools.RasterRegionCombineMode)
member.summary: Sets or updates the object that describes this current region.
member.param: object that LEADTOOLS uses to translate between display coordinates and image coordinates. If you specify null (Nothing in Visual Basic) for this parameter, the scalar fields default to 1, the offsets default to 0, and the view perspective defaults to the image view perspective.
A object to set or update into this . If this parameter is an empty region or null (Nothing in Visual Basic), then the current region in the image will be deleted (this is the equivalent of calling .
The action to take regarding the existing image region, if one is defined.

remarks.para: To get the object that describes the current image region, use .
To update an existing region, you specify how the new region is to be combined with the existing one using the parameter. For more information, refer to .

member.param: object that LEADTOOLS uses to translate between display coordinates and image coordinates. If you specify null (Nothing in Visual Basic) in this parameter, the scalar fields default to 1, the offsets default to 0, and the view perspective defaults to the image view perspective.

A collection of objects. The points in the collection must be in the order in which the vertices of the polygon are connected. To create the line that closes the polygon, the last point in the collection is connected to the first point of the collection.

param.name: fillMode
param.para: Indicates how to handle complex crossing lines.

tr.td: All pixels that are inside the resulting exterior lines are in the region.
The region includes the area between odd-numbered and even-numbered polygon sides on each scan line.

member.param: The action to take regarding the existing image region, if one is defined.

remarks.para: To update an existing region, you specify how the new region is to be combined with the existing one using the parameter. For more information, refer to .
For more information, refer to Creating a Region.
For more information, refer to Saving A Region.
For more information, refer to Working with the Existing Region.

member.example: This example will load an image, adds a bezier curve region to it, run the InvertCommand to show the affected area before saving the image back to disk.

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.AddColorRgbRangeToRegion(Leadtools.RasterColor,Leadtools.RasterColor,Leadtools.RasterRegionCombineMode)
member.summary: Creates or updates the image region by adding a region that consists of all the pixels that fall in the given RGB color range.
member.param: Specifies the minimum (inclusive) R, G and B values. A pixel must have R,G, and B all greater than or equal to and less than or equal to to be included in the region.
Specifies the maximum (inclusive) R, G and B values. A pixel must have R,G, and B all greater than or equal to and less than or equal to to be included in the region.
The action to take regarding the existing image region, if one is defined.

remarks.para: This method uses the RGB color model to set a region based on a color range.
To be added to the region a color must fall in the range ... To set a region for all pure red, specify and as follows:
Note that this would fail to include many colors that look red to the eye (like RGB(255,4,4)).

This method supports 12 and 16-bit grayscale and 48 and 64-bit color images. Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale and 48 and 64-bit color images is available only in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
To update an existing region, you specify how the new region is to be combined with the existing one using the parameter. For more information, refer to .
For more information, refer to Creating a Region.
For more information, refer to Saving A Region.
For more information, refer to Working with the Existing Region.

member.example: This example will load an image, adds a region corresponding to all colors that have an RGB that includes green but no red and no blue, run the InvertCommand to show the affected area before saving the image back to disk.
member.seealso: Introduction: Bits Per Pixel and Related Ideas

member.name: M:Leadtools.RasterImage.AddColorHsvRangeToRegion(Leadtools.RasterHsvColor,Leadtools.RasterHsvColor,Leadtools.RasterRegionCombineMode)
member.summary: Creates or updates the image region by adding a region that consists of all the pixels that fall in the given HSV color range.
member.param: Specifies the minimum (inclusive) R, G and B values. A pixel must have H,S, and V all greater than or equal to and less than or equal to to be included in the region.
Specifies the maximum (inclusive) R, G and B values. A pixel must have H,S, and V all greater than or equal to and less than or equal to to be included in the region.
The action to take regarding the existing image region, if one is defined.

remarks.para: This method uses the HSV color model to set a region based on a color range.
It is useful for identifying all shades of a certain color. For example, this method could be used to set a region of all green colors including:
The diagram below shows how S and V affect the color green (H = 85):
To be added to the region a color must fall in the range .... If you want to set a region for all red (and colors near red), you could specify and as follows:

The hue for the lowerColor is 250 and the hue for the upperColor is 5. For the hue to fall in this range it must be 250, 251, 252, 253, 254, 255, 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5. Note that the values for hue wrap from 255 to 1.

This method supports 12 and 16-bit grayscale and 48 and 64-bit color images. Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale and 48 and 64-bit color images is available only in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
This method does not support signed data images.
To update an existing region, you specify how the new region is to be combined with the existing one using the parameter. For more information, refer to .
For more information, refer to Creating a Region.
For more information, refer to Saving A Region.
For more information, refer to Working with the Existing Region.

member.example: This example will load an image, adds a region corresponding to all pure green (Hue = 85) and colors near green (+/- 10), run the InvertCommand to show the affected area before saving the image back to disk.
member.seealso: Introduction: Bits Per Pixel and Related Ideas

For more information, refer to Working with the Existing Region.

For more information, refer to Saving A Region.
